reviewText:
The short version: Fun MMO/ARPG/Loot Dropper (Diablo, Torchlight, Sacred, Path of Exile, etc) game with a Marvel skin that's free to play (F2P) and pay to look good. Fun and pretty good about in game purchases.

In Detail
At this point, I've played two characters (Cable & Dr. Strange) fairly extensively but not to max level and some of the others up to the level 10 cap. You can of course pay (either real money or time gated in game currency) to uncap other characters and it seems worthwhile to do so (the slow free option does anyway) since every character I've played has felt different from the others even if they function the same way. There also isn't the overused tank, dps, support character type mechanic which for me is a plus (though some characters are definitely tankier than others).

Being F2P, there are of course some things that you can't get (or are very unlikely to get) without paying real money. Unlike many games with this monetization scheme, it doesn't really bother me as most of what's on offer is cosmetic or a variation on something you can get through other means and isn't pushed too hard (at least so far).

The gameplay itself is repetitive but fun. You'll take on hordes of enemies, most of which will die from a single shot if you're playing an area at level, with a few tougher ones thrown in for something to use your powers on besides a boss. Difficulty varies depending on the character as some are significantly less durable than others, but this generally fits the character as expected and as long as you can keep an eye on your health while fighting actually dying is a rarity.

On the whole, I'd recomend it as an F2P title since it doesn't have any pay to win" mechanics that I've seen (yet) and is fun to play
date: especially with friends.\n\nI'll probably update this review when/if I reach Lvl 60 and see what the end game is like."

Average Diablo-like that uses exclusive mouse only control.
Immersion breaking experience as you watch 30 of the same hero wander by.

Zones are open world, you will not be having an instanced Diablo experience like they tote it being. Its just really akward.

Your starter heroes are: The Thing, Scarlet Witch, Dare Devil, Hawk Eye, and Storm
You will recieve an additional hero after the tutorial, but it seems to be random.

As is melee is at a huge disadvantage, turret style bosses rely on tagging them, fleeing, repeating. You won't be slugging it out with them regardless of character.

Biggest greivance is there is no hero preview system, you are expected to shell out cash for a new hero or wait for it to random drop before you get to play it.

reviewText:
This game is a blast!  I played at launch and wasn't too impressed.  However, since then they have made many improvements and added a ton of heroes.  I will list the PROS and CONS from my experience so far:

PROS

* Plays great on even lower end hardware

* Graphics are surprisingly good.  The character models aren't amazing, but the spell/power effects and such are a lot of fun to look at.

* Combat is fun and fast-paced.  Some issues will be listed in CONS.

* Hero build diversity is the cornerstone to this game IMHO.  Each hero is its own distinct class.  How many ARPGs out there have so many classes??  And they're from the Marvel universe to boot!

* Story is comic-style and pretty fun.  It isn't really required for more playthroughs, but fun the first time.

* MOST content is obtainable via ingame currency.  You can earn heroes and most good stuff if you play enough and play smart.  There is something here for casual and hardcore min/maxers alike.

* Heroes can be played for free to level 10.  Then you can pick 1 for a free unlock.  So much better than it was earlier in the game's lifespan.

CONS

* It can be a little overwhelming and complex for new players.  I suggest checking Youtube for new players, especially those new to the ARPG genre.  Wilfred Wong is my favorite presenter on there as he explains things well, while still having some endgame knowledge for those looking to optimize.  Don't look to him for min-max, but he's a very nice guy and worth a look for beginner/intermediate players.

* Inventory is insane.  You need to really understand what is and isn't worth keeping, which will take time.  If you have a large roster of heroes, it is EXTREMELY difficult to avoid having to buy space from Gazillion.  But, the game is free, so I personally don't mind paying for something, it's fun afterall.

* Like any MMO-style ARPG, open world content can be a little nuts.  It's usually a zerg race to bosses/quest targets, as better geared players can melt down just about anything in a couple seconds or so.  But respawn isn't terrible and you can get what you need if you watch the map.

TLDR: It's a fun game for Marvel fans and ARPG fans alike.  I say give it a little time if you feel overwhelmed with it all.  Check the Youtube I mentioned and hope you have fun!!!

reviewText:
I've put about a billion hours into this game in the last two or three weeks because it's scratching an itch that had begun festering after I got sick of Diablo 2 and never really reached. Path of Exile was too muddy and I'm not playing a god damn all-passives sphere grid like some degenerate Final Fantasy clone. Torchlight 2 is fun but it's more a game of mods than a game of game. Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is fun but makes my tower fan scream and weep because it is full of bad optimization ghosts.

Marvel Heroes is a free-to-play Diablo-like that feels less free-to-play than Diablo 3. The character choices are fun and wildly varied. The Punisher threatens to shoot Spider-Man if you idle next to him in base. Emma Frost passive-aggressively snipes at everyone.

It is an enjoyable game, for me, a huge nerd.

reviewText:
Do you enjoy the loot fest of Diablo? Do you wish Torchlight 2 had a constant community to interact with ingame? Do you enjoy Path of Exile, but sometimes want an easier and less hardcore experience? Then Marvel Heroes might be your go to game this summer!
Don't let reviewers shy you away from the game because a lot of its problems from last June have been fixed (mostly). The game does still have its problems and shortcomings. As of writing this they still do not have a proper trade menu, which every MMO ever has gotten right if they were made in the past decade.
Characters are imbalanced but a lot of the free starter characters offer fun diverse playstyles. After completing story mode you'll be offered the ability to get another free one. Heroes are no longer random drops, but rather awarded to you for playing long periods of time. The only real thing that only money can buy is storage space.
Yes this game is not as great as Dota2 or Path of Exile at the Free2Play Model, but it isn't the worst anymore. All heroes have been marked down since the original release and are (for the most part) priced fairly for the amount of time a person invests in the hero. There's also a server called Test Center that allows you to test out a character at the max level, to see if you'll enjoy the character before ever buying them. Something that was a major problem at the game's initial release.
Honestly the game has come a long way since last June. However the lack of a trade system, quickly running into inventory management, no autosort option for items, weird chat UI, and lack of partying incentive during the grind from 1 to 60... really holds the game back from being a major recommendation. However if you're a fan and want to try a new Diablo style lootfest, Marvel Heroes might be worth your time.

reviewText:
This game ranks as one of the best free to play games on Steam as of this writing.

A game similar in feel and gameplay to the Diablo and Torchlight games, only you get to play through as your favorite Marvel heroes (and a few villains) - with new characters being introduced regularly. The initial character selection is limited to a few basic heroes, but complete the story mode and you will unlock another random hero for free. Additionally, while you can pay real money to unlock any hero you want (as well as customizing them with various costumes), you can earn every hero in the game for free by collecting Eternity Splinters that drop from time to time.

Gameplay is pretty straightforward. Click on an enemy to attack them, with up to six special ability hotkeys (and plenty of skills to choose from). One downside is that many heroes play very similarly at the earlier levels, though you do begin to see some differences as you progress and unlock new abilities, with every hero having a unique ultimate attack that can be unlocked and upgraded.

Loot is a big draw here. Like all Diablo-style games, loot will drop regularly and in the familiar rarities (grey garbage, white normal, green uncommon, blue rare, purple epic) as well as a few others (yellow cosmics, red artifacts, gold uniques). Old loot can be sold or 'donated' to a shopkeeper which will, over time, upgrade that shopkeeper so that he or she will offer better items or services.

Another benefit of this game is that there are many events that take place which offer chances to get items for free that you might otherwise have to pay for. And speaking of paying for items... this is hardly a 'pay to win' game. Sure, you can pay for an experience boost if you want to level up faster, or you can pay for a potion that will give you a better chance at scoring really good loot, but most pay items are cosmetic. Costumes, pets, and so forth. And while pets can give you small boosts to your stats over time, you can earn free pets that do the same thing.

While it isn't exactly breaking any new ground or stepping into new territory, Marvel Heroes is a great game to pass the time either solo or with friends, and if you ever get stuck, the community is generally quite helpful to newer players. I'd recommend this game to anyone, even non-gamers.
voteText: 45 of 84 people (54%) found this review helpful 7 people found this review funny

reviewText:
First off, it's an ARPG not an MMO, so don't go thinking it's WOW with Marvel characters. Secondly, your customisation options are very limited - it's a Marvel game and they're ferociously protective of their characters' images, so apart from the preset costumes you're basically limited to cosmetic effects like glowing auras, you can't customise your characters' appearance to any real degree.

In terms of gameplay, it's a pretty solid Diablo clone, the different characters all play sufficiently differently to each other to make it interesting, and you can unlock all the characters for free if you're patient enough. There's some things you can't earn ingame - such as additional bank slots - and some like costumes which you can theoretically earn in game, but the drop rates are absolutely terrible. But it's just cosmetic and quality-of-life stuff which you need to buy, if you don't mind a bit of grinding you can unlock everything else without paying anything.

Ultimately it comes down to how much of a Marvel fan you are - there are better ARPGs on the market, but none of them have such a strong brand behind them, and if you're even a casual fan of the comics, cartoon series or films, being able to play as the characters will probably be all the counragement you need. And if you're still not sure, it's competely free to play with no restrictions on what free players can access, so you may as well give it a go and see for yourself whether you like it.

reviewText: After playing through the story mode and leveling my first hero up, I figured I'd post a review. I thoroughly enjoy this game. It's made by the original creators of Diablo and Diablo II so it has that feel to it, which works surprisingly well in the Marvel universe. Although a lot of the content can be paid for to unlock, you can also earn 90% of it in-game, without having to spend a dime. It's pretty well balanced, so that it doesn't take a ridiculously long time to earn something. You don't feel like your hand is being twisted to buy things with real money, which is a breath of fresh air in games like this.\n\nThe graphics are above average, if you don't have a decent PC it will struggle a little bit. The gameplay is pretty much identical to Diablo and similar action RPG games. There's a lot to this game I could spend hours talking about, but overall I would definitely recommend it. After all it's free.

reviewText: What do you get when you take the base gameplay/advancement system of diablo 2, spend another year developing end game content, and wrap it all up inside a skin of Marvel Superheroes? You get an excellent game, that's what! The game is truly free-to-play requiring nothing to be spent for anything in the game (except time played if you want to buy more heroes). Of course like any good f2p game you can optionally spend money to buy exactly what you want when you want it. No matter what though, either way you approach Marvel Heroes 2015 you are in for a treat. The only real downside to the game is the same downside to every single ARPG. I gets VERY grindy at the end. Fortunately rather than just grinding the end-game indefinitely, new heroes (classes) are released every single month. On top of that so far a handful of new game modes have been added every few months or so as well. For fans of ARPGs, and especially those looking for a f2p game that doesn't feel or play like you would expect a f2p title to feel/play, Marvel 2015 gets a VERY easy recommendation.

reviewText:
Pros

+ARPG like Torchlight/PoE/Diablo
+Marvel Super Heroes!
+Comic lore
+So many characters to choose from
+You dont need to buy anything to play effectively.
+Raids!
+Endless wave modes like X-defense and Midtown!
+SO MUCH LOOT!
+Plenty of endgame content
+The Developers are dedicated everyday to making this game better and always adding more content!

Cons

-Needs more optimization.
-Sometimes there are little glitches within the story scenes, but easy to overcome.
-Not enough room for items considering all the characters in the game that is free. You have to buy the extra spaces for more storage, but its not that bad of a price I guess, considering how you play.
-No real punishment when your character dies. I guess that would be aimed towards the casual player vs the hardcore?
-Some character balancing issues, but most often fixed. So I guess its nothing to get worried about too much.
-Crafting is not the greatest, but its there. Yay for options!
-Trade system needs a lot of work.

Totally worth the FREE! Very good game for the Marvel fans! Gazillion has done a superb job on delivering a really good videogame. Overall, a really enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
The game is fun but it does have its limit on the fun. Despite all the negativity it received, the Marvel Heroes 2015 plays like a different game, far fetch on how it used to be.

I started off with my all time favorite one liner Rocket Racoon and had a blast pew-pewing through mobs afte mobs hunger for loots but such cycle starts to get bored fast after a certain time and you will eventually hit the wall and cry for a break before the urge of playing comes back.

Unlike any other games you play, MH2015 plays near identically close to Diablo franchise and the storyline takes a couple of quick hours to be completed and the rest of your time spent on will be on Midtown Madness or any other challenges just to name a few.

MH2015 can be fulfilled as a short-term entertainment but lack of the motivation to stay long as your primary game. I would still recommend the game to anyone who are interested in playing and it may not fit well in everyone's shoes.

Its a free game, there isnt any harm trying. Give yourself a week of play time to see if MH2015 is for you.

reviewText: The Marvel Universe has a character for everyone to enjoy, and you can pick from a lot of them from here, and the list is growing still.  The gameplay is fun and satisfying, I don't notice much of a grind just loving running around smashing AIM goons' faces in with elbow drops from She Hulk or an uppercut from Ant Man, or just eating them as Venom.  I actually have had more positive interactions with social chats than any other game I have seen, but of course, chats can get toxic as with anything else, be ready for those small moments.  Game is pretty simple, but still has some things to delve into.  You can choose to grind for THE BEST gear, but honestly, you don't need to.  Game is free to play fair, I got two heroes I really liked for free, and played them a lot, but then when I felt like I loved the game, I payed for some inventory and a few more heroes I really wanted.\nIf you like MARVEL this game is great!  If you want to get into MARVEL this is also great!  If you want a time killer with some fun and simple combat Diablo style, also great!\nIf you somehow can only see any game with loot as a farm fest, then no, but then you wouldn't even look at a game like this, let alone a review, right?

reviewText: Marvel Heroes won't win any prizes for originality, but it is an extremely fun game in its own right that makes effective use of the license at its disposal, and it's always refreshing to encounter a free-to-play title that is intended to be precisely that.You can play Marvel Heroes through without spending any money on it, and it will be a decent experience for you. However, the inelegant handling of multiple characters, along with the lack of any real difficulty means that it doesn’t quite reach the heights of other games in the genre. But it is the only game of its type where you can play as your favourite Marvel characters and that is certainly something that will draw many people in.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At launch, Marvel Heroes was a huge mess.

But since then, the game has improved by leaps and bounds. Constant updates, hero reworks, new game modes, special events.... I´m actually having a lot of fun playing it!

There´s a large selection of heroes and they play/feel different enough to make you want to unlock multiple heroes.

The free to play model is fair... you can unlock every heroe just by playing, although it takes a ridiculous amount of time.
Only things you can´t unlock by just playing are extra bank space and some costumes for your heroes.

If you enjoy action rpgs, Marvel Heroes is worth taking a look at.

The game is fun to play, looks good, animations are well done, the devs are very active on the forums, the community is very nice and helpfull and heck, you get to play 30+ different heroes from the Marvel Universe.

Granted, if mindlessly killing waves upon waves of mobs looking for loot is not your cup of tea, this might not be the game for you. But if you are looking for a game to fill the void left by the trainwreck that was Diablo 3 and don´t feel like dealing with Path of Exile over complicated talent tree and (IMO) ugly graphics, Marvel Heroes provides a good, satisfying time for casual players.

reviewText: Marvel Heroes Review\n\nMarvel Heroes launch wasn’t the best but has definitely changed from an average game to a fun and enjoyable game. Marvel Heroes has a large roster of heroes to choose from and while you can acquire them through micro-transactions it is completely optional, you can get all the heroes through collecting “eternity splinters” which you can trade them off for heroes of your choice. While getting heroes can be done at the cost of nothing, getting “fancy” new costumes for your heroes does cost money. Marvel Heroes has a large storyline which you can play through and the developers constantly add more and more chapters, might I say you can play through the whole storyline for free if you’re wondering. Marvel Heroes is if you haven’t guessed yet is a lot like Diablo so if you’re a fan of that game and a fan of marvel then this game is perfect for you. There are lots to do in Marvel Heroes from occasional events, players vs. players and lots of different things you can do after you have finished the story. Overall Marvel Heroes is a well made game and because it’s free, there is no reason not to try it out.

reviewText: The game is masterful.  There are tons of characters to choose from and it is put together with David Brevik at the helm.  Gazillion is the most active development team with the community right now and I love the effort they are putting into this game.  This game was horrible when it first launched and now, it is incredibly good.\n\nIf you're wondering if this game is for you, ask yourself if you loved Diablo 2.  That's what this game is trying to become and it's getting closer and closer with each patch.  I'm much older now than when I was a teenager playing Diablo 2 and even I wondered if this would scratch that nostalgic itch.  For me, it did and it is my favorite game out right now.  I'm not a comic reader and don't follow anything in Marvel at all, but I just love this game.  It's my perfect ARPG and I can't wait to see how it progresses over time.  I'd recommend this game to ANY ARPG fan out there since it's free and it's only getting better.

reviewText:
First off, don't let the Metacritic rating scare you off.  Everyone who played it at launch fully admits that the game was ♥♥♥ on toast then.  Currently, Marvel Heroes is a fantastic ARPG well worth looking at.

Unlike a lot of ARPGs that have come down the pike since Diablo 2, what the devs at Gazillion rightly realize is that the reason that D2 was so beloved was that it's just plain fun to mow down gigantic hordes of mooks like a hot knife through butter, slowing down only to sort your loot or focus on a boss (or four).  The source material fits perfectly with this gameplay - of course Iron Man or Hulk can smash through absurdly large numbers of foes without breaking a sweat, something would be wrong if they couldn't.

Couple this with attack effects as flashy as you'd expect from comic books (and the fact that you can't help blowing up/breaking virtually everything in sight) and it's basically the perfect ARPG for the ADD set.

Moreover, Marvel Heroes is massively generous as a free to play game; you've got 9 different characters to choose from at start and every single character in the game can be unlocked for free just by playing the game.  Sure, you can buy characters with money if you want but don't feel like you have to in order to play the game, most of the starters are perfectly viable.  The only thing that absolutely can't be gotten via just playing is extra stash space, but by the time you've played long enough to really need/want more you'll probably have gotten enough entertainment value to lay down a few bucks.

Gazillion is a developer that patches and updates the game incredibly often (sometimes too often, but they're getting better) and they're fantastic with communicating with the playerbase.  New heroes are coming out pretty much every month.

This is not the hardest ARPG around, and it can get a bit repetitive at times, but it's well worth checking out and a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Clearly this game need a re-rate!! After stopping for sometime, decided to load it up and see what is new :) glad i did. this game is very well a gem at the moment.

It has a bad launch with un-optimised engine, bad contents, bad special effects, bad balance, junk inventory items (e.g. crafting items). Just bad of everything.
I actually managed to get few friends to play with me during that time. All left with a bad taste in the mouth after a week or two. It was because of the inventory hog and has the feeling that developer just wants you to spend on the F2P game.

Now all of these crafting items are more managable with stacking. but somehow they have reintroduced another inventory hog- Relics.. sigh..

There are now a lot more things to do in the game and more items to collect for you hero item slots. Also lots of modes has been introduced. Midtown Mahanthan is just brilliant. You can be in there the whole day clearing the mobs there. mobs are also more varied than it used to be.

There is also Heroic and more difficlt modes for you to relive the story mission and get better equipments.

There are lots more contents but i am no real reviewer.. :p

i would give this a 80/100 for what it is now.

Be going back to my marvel game now..

reviewText: Put in over 20 hours.  This game has great potential.  I love all the different characters and the gameplay is fun.  However this game still needs a lot of work.  It's structured poorly when doing quests or trying to follow a poor excuse for a story.  I found myself wasting a lot of time wandering around just to do a single quest because many of them have no quest tracker to tell you where it's at.  This gets really annoying.  I compare this game to diablo 3 naturally and it just seems to need an awful lot of work and improvement.  Till then I'm done for now.  For those just looking to play the game for the sake of grinding and destroying things and not caring for a great story or a well structured game, knock yourselves out.  Hopefully the Devs put alot of work into updating the story and make the quests easier to find as well as a better mini map.  Do this and I may come back.

reviewText:
Well, I felt the need to clarify some things as recent reviews have been negative, and there is NO good reason for this.

The Draws:
A must for Marvel comic fans, as this is very true to the source material, while still including enough of the Marvel Cinematic Universe references to delight the fans of only the movies.
The art and banter in this game are fantastic. This game is chock full of flavorful tidbits that delight in every sense.
The customization for builds is nearly limitless and the same hero can be in a group with two different builds and feel like two totally different heroes.
The endgame is MASSIVE. There are a lot of things to do once at max level, and the game even has options to rerun the level up process for your favorites, with some cool benefits for those who choose to do so.
Solid gameplay and controls. This game feels very polished and complete. Brevik's team knows their stuff.
The game is genuinely and oftentimes GLORIOUSLY fun.
This is how Free-to-Play SHOULD be done. You have access to most things without ever LOOKING at a store to spend real money. If you are willing to put in the time and effort, you can get access to whatever your heart desires (for the most part).

The Turn-offs:
Lack of fresh content. Though there is a full storyline mode, it feels short (which the game has on 3 difficulty modes, so you run it 3 times to totally complete the story on a character). The One-Shots and Raids have their own storylines, but they are mostly setups to boss fights, and not a ton of character progression. The new Ultron game mode also has a story, but it isn't anything to be impressed about.
Depending on who your favorite character is, you may be completely useless in a raid setting, being forced to level up a raid-appropriate character to run on if you wish to participate in raids.
Repetition. This game has it. In spades. This game has it. In spades. Repetition.

Summary:
This game is worth playing through and is a very solid MMO that is fun. There is stuff constantly being added to the game and plenty of events in which to participate. So Assemble your team and get to Smashing.
Excelsior!

(P.S. Plenty of cameos. Including a few by his royal Generalissimo, Stan The Man.)

reviewText:
Wow yeah, where to start.

I will give this game a fair review from my perspective.

This f2p game is actually quite good since you can get all the things in the game without paying for anything except for stash, with that said you will have to invest alot of hours into it that way.
There is alot of Heroes to choose from, some are unique, some heroes got the same skill as another but reskinned and some are just uninteresting.
The power effects that the heroes have are in most cases really good, it looks good to destroy the screen with lightning, magic and laser beams.

This game is an arpg much like Diablo 2, it got a story mode, it got kill everything you see zones, it got raids and diffrent levels of difficulties.
Everything which will feel very repetitive after awhile as you are trying to get the item drops that you want.

I can't help to feel that this game is shallow somehow and I have tried to like this game but it just doesn't connect with me.



Then we have the store in this game.
It is really, really overpriced and I don't see an excuse to why it is that expensive.
If you want to unlock all the characters in this game without spending alot of hours, then it will have the same price as 3-4 AAA games at release.
This game is good for being a f2p game but it's not that good that it will overshadow 3-4 AAA games worth of price just to have access to the whole game, as in being able to play all of the heroes.
Stash will be your biggest problem as a f2p gamer in this game, you will not be able hold alot of items in this game as a f2p gamer.
You have several diffrent relics that drops, runes, artifacts, crafter items, gear and what not.
Trust me it will fill your singel free stash space quickly and yes stash space costs you real money.




So now to a problem I stumbled upon in this game is the very sensitive nature of the chat in this game.
If you invest money in this game then stay away from the social/public chat in this game because your opinion or something that you wrote might very well be taken out of context and have you banned, either 7 days ban or permanently.
This server is hosted in the USA and their ''freedom of speech'' is heavily moderated.
Don't engage in religion, political, racist or sexist discussion or jokes, someone somewhere is going to get butthurt.
Someone might report you and you might lose all your invested money into the game if you get permanently banned.
That is going to sting since the store prices are really overpriced.

I got banned for 7 days for something I wrote that was cut out of its context and thus the text I wrote was seen as hate speech, admittadly I did have poor choice of wording and that together with cutting my sentence out of its context that the rest of the chat was invested in got me banned.

I fooled around in chat like I do in several other games but never have I been even warned or banned for that matter in my whole life as a gamer.
My best guess is that I have never been playing on server hosted outside of Europe and thus never felt the crazy restraint of speech before like I have done from a server hosted in the USA.
As an exampel I did some research about it and found that a guy got 7 days banned from writing in the chat that ''Hulk is gay'', whether or not that is true I can't confirm but I wouldn't be suprised if it was.


I am thankful and happy to be living in Europe and God bless all the nations in it and the people.





TL;DR:  Test the game you might like it but don't engage in the chat about outwordly things even if the chat is called SOCIAL, some americans are very touchy.

I don't recommend this game because for me its a money grabbing game but it's worth a try if you truly go f2p.
If you decide to spend money in the game then for the sake of your wallet don't engage with the chat, you might get banned.

reviewText:
Well its been about 6 months since the last time I wrote a review on this game (gave it about a 5.7/10 as it had many flaws), and I recently just got back into Marvel Heroes and felt that it was appropriate to update my review on the game. Marvel Heroes as a game has grown a whole lot since its really bad release. Various numbers and formulas have changed for damage calculating, and heroes have been revamped (making OP heroes less OP while making the boring and weak heroes a hell of a lot more fun).

Since my departure from the game, I can't say that a whole lot of content has been added, because it hasn't. However, end game content has been revised and the game as a whole gets better each week thanks to the Devs working really REALLY close with the community in terms of QA and asking the players how each Hero feels with each and every new patch that is released.

In terms of the f2p of the game, the heroes arent as pricey, they are all much more acceptable with most of them costing less than 10 dollars, leaving a small few which include IronMan, Deadpool and Spider-Man (and maybe one or two more I cannot remember) costing around 12 bucks. With costumes still being roughly the same price they always were (varrying from 10 for the average skin and 20 for a Enhanced skin) as that is now their main source of revenue. But this is all because Heroes are much more easy to obtain in game now with the addition of a new currency that the player earns as they play overtime. With the currency players can now save up to purchase their desired hero (for varrying costs) or can opt-in for a much cheaper gacha bag" option where the player buys a random hero at a reduced price.

All in all I recommend checking out this game if you are at least a fan of ARPGs

recommended: however I have no doubt that it is getting there. If you don't believe me check out their weekly patch notes
hoursPlayed: its crazy how many things are changed each and everytime.\n\n7.6/10....for now!"

reviewText:
All of these negative reviews you see are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Don't listen to them. This is a wonderful game that is absolutely worth your time, especially if you're a fan of ARPGs such as Diablo, Torchlight, the Sacred series, etc.

It plays EXACTLY like them, but in the Marvel universe, with marvel characters. And boy, are there a lot of characters to play as. There's over 40 I believe, and they just keep adding to that number semi-frequently.

There are three difficulties to play. You start in normal mode, and as you complete the campaign mode, you'll unlock the other two. The higher difficulties will give you better loot drops, more gold, more experience, etc.

This game has a lot of unique things going on that make it even more sensational. There's an omega system, which is basically paragon levels from D3, but it's really interesting, and there's a TON of variety, which in turn, makes customizing your character almost an endless affair. You can do so many things with one hero, it's amazing.

There's this feature called Team-ups" which I think are pretty cool as well. They're essentially pets
date: but in the form of other heroes that'll tag along with you. However
recommended: you can outfit them and customize their abilities as well
hoursPlayed: so it really adds even more depth to your ever-growing ARPG OCD :P\n\nThere's also PvP and group play
voteText: which is to be expected from an online game. Group play is pretty cool
helpfulPercent: as you'll drop down in an area and team up with nearby heroes to take down tough baddies. Don't worry though
votesHelpful: there's no fighting over loot
votesTotal: it all drops seperately for each character.\n\nHonestly
votesFunny: it's just great fun. If you love superheroes
commentsCount: if you love ARPGs
column16: it's the perfect match for you. You can purchase every hero/team-up in the game for free. The currency
column17: eternity splinters
column18: drop frequently and a person is more than capable of not spending a dime on this game. That being said
column19: you have nothing to lose
column20: and I guarentee you'll have some fun if you give it a shot."

reviewText:
Free.
Not Pay 2 Win.
Better than Diablo 3.
Maybe better than Diablo 2 if you ignore nostalgia.
Monthly Content Updates.
Tons of Unique Heroes that are all interesting and fun to build/gear.
All heroes can be unlocked in game. Takes about a month to get enough currency to get a new hero.
So by the time your done with one your unlocking the next.
Great Community with helpful unitimidating players except for Raids which are built to attract the best Min/Max type players.
Made by David Brevik the inventor of Diablo
It has a Cow Level.
It has a Cosmic Cow Level.
You can play as Star-Lord.
You can play as Psylocke.
You can play as Rocket Racoon. He has a giant robot mechwarrior move...
Wolverine is a beast.
Black Panther is a smooth ninja.
Iron Man is awesome and has the One-Off" power from IM 2.
Ms. Marvel is amazing in this game and makes me want a movie about her now.
Gambit...and Night Crawler...and... Loki... and ... eventually Venom and Magento???
This game is awesome.
Try it and stick with it until you have tried 5 or so heroes and gotten a few to level 60.
The End Game gear/loot mechanics are actually pretty cool and more compelx than they initially seem.
You can play 10 mintues or 10 hrs and still enjoy it.

Almost infinite replay value because of the almost infinite hero roster and expanding content.

Try it. Keep an open mind. Its Marvel Diablo. Its my favorite game of 2013/2014/2015"

reviewText: During the beta, the game was pretty bad, so I put it away. Came back to it recently after hearing about the changes and despite the stigma of a free to play... it is incredibly fun. You can unlock heroes without money in an expected amount of time. The hardest thing to do without spending money, is inventory control. You won't have access to a ton of inventory slots so you would need to be careful. But the game is worth 40 dollars. I had 50 hours in easy. No plan to stop. So throwing 10-20 bucks at later on for quality of life is a no brainer. I have paid a lot of more games that kept me a lot less entertained and of a much lower quality. Heroes is excellent. Beyond that, the crew that works on the game is amazing. The devs join in on streams, they listen to the community. We vote on new hero releases. It is definitely worth your time and if you want to definitely worth a couple dollars later on.

reviewText:
This game has problems, most of them quite boring.
So let's talk about the interesting problem, immersion.

In a universe where players can control the Hulk yet are still mortal, can be Iron Man or Thor yet need to walk around iron fences in their path or be Spiderman yet never have a convoluted dance sequence, there is something wrong.
Having players be the big-name heroes is the main appeal of the game, but also its main problem since they must be weaker than they should be.
The fact that there are thousands of Spider Men players walking around is explained by Doctor Doom breaking reality, and honestly the source material is sufficiently out there that it actually works, but Vision being knocked out by half a dozen of street thugs just breaks immersion.

The solution? Pick somebody that doesn't really have super powers, which in my case was Black Widow.
Suddenly things felt a lot nicer. Overcoming challenges felt more in line with the character, and beating a C-List villain after a long boss battle feels satisfying instead of weird.

So, if you try out the game, do yourself a favour and pick a character that shouldn't" be that strong
date: and you'll have a far better time.\nBeyond that very specific gripe it's a decent
hoursPlayed: very run of the mill isometric MMORPG. There's a decent main plot
voteText: tons of barely distinguishable loot
helpfulPercent: a pile of monetization mechanics (but no "stamina" or avoidable revive penalty or something
votesHelpful: so it's not quite that bad).\nAs a free game it's worth a look
votesTotal: whether you stick with it is very much dependent on your resistance to tedium."
commentsCount: true

reviewText:
Game started out with little to do other than level your Gazillion characters after post game on a boss run. Since release the game has improved with their monthly patches adding more to the story and endgame content to make grinding less monotonous with multiple ways to level and find loot. Developers listen to the community and constantly makes improvements with to the heroes and game play.

Starting Hero's are decent but be careful. Once you select one of the starters you will have to stick with that one until you find one via the drop system or buy one via collecting shards in game or real money. I think they should give you 2 starts to try to avoid slight stress on what to pick first.

It's a fun game. I would give it a shot if you want Diablo with Marvel characters. I spend a few hours on it a week. Its a good time killer if anything. I expect this game to grow and maybe reach enjoyment and serious levels of an mmo like DC Universe Online.

Also there is no cow level :p

reviewText: I have played this game far too much since it's release, and it's come a long way since then! Six months ago I would've not recommended this game and not given it a second thought. I'm really glad I decided to pick it up again recently, all of the new additions to the game have made it much more fun and a bit addicting. I'm often hesitant about free to play games of this style as I have found they usually tend to have a large amount of important content that needs to be bought to really play the entire game. I have found that's really not the case here. While there may be a few convenience issues for non-paying players (primarily in STASH space) the payment model is actually quite fair, with nearly everything in the game available through in-game currencies, including every hero and team-up hero. If you like the Marvel universe, or ARPGs in general you should definitely give it a shot.

reviewText: This is Diablo 2's true spiritual successor. Forget PoE and Diablo 3.  This is Diablo 2 set in the Marvel Universe and feels much more fresh than D3 or PoE due to it's visual style, setting, and combat system (lol @ D3).  Upgrades come frequently, and there's a very definite path to acquire upgrades.  Not as customizable as D2 or PoE, but there is enough to keep you busy.  Oh, and lets add in mmo style raids in an Action RPG.  Free to play and pay for convenience is the name of this game.  And an awesome system to leveling alts that every MMO should copy.

reviewText:
No Idea where people are getting some of their reviews from. must be playing a different game to me.

Firstly Since release there has been alot of improvements to the game and plentry of content released. They tend to release a new playable Hero each month as well as weekly bug fixes and some other content such as weekend events etc.

In terms of Content it is releasing PvP and Raids in Beta with Raids being out of Beta in a few weeks. Also other game modes are added such as X-Defense which is a wave based mode which was not implented on release. One Shot terminals which are small story arcs. Shared Quests that allow you to group up. Plus there is other stuff coming in the coming months such as Endless Dungeons.

Now to the Free to Play part. People who say this is pay to win are clearly unaware that all heroes can be bought without spending a penny. Yes it will take time to earn but the game is by no means pay to win. the only thing you will need to purchase is bank space and even that is not a necesity if you can keep your inventory tidy and are willing to not horde items.

Finally the Devs. Anyone who does go on the forums for this game will be aware of how active the devs are. They take alot of community feedback on board and try to gear the game to be enjoyed by the player.

If your not a superhero fan then maybe this isnt for you as much but it is a great way to get into the universe of Marvel.

Brilliant Game and Enjoyable for most ages in my opinion. 10/10 and best superhero game i have played

reviewText:
Marvel Heroes is a ActionRPG type game by Gazillion and from the original creator of Diablo.

Some of you might remember playing Marvel: Ultimate Alliance back on the PS2, this is very similar to those types of games except you’re playing with lots of other people and have a massive roster of heroes to choose from.

There is a crafting element to Marvel Heroes where you can level up vendors and crafters to unlock new recipes and gear augmentations. There are a few things to do besides playing the story missions of the game such as the open public dungeon Mid-town Manhattan and specific challenge terminals with a boss at the end, you can also queue up for X-Defence which is a survive as many waves of enemies as you can solo or with a group, and the Fire vs Ice PVP arena. More content is arriving monthly with new story missions and challenge terminals and of course new heroes and new costumes.

FREE TO PLAY:
When you create an account over at https://marvelheroes.com/ and login to the game from Steam you will be able to select one free “starter hero” from a pre-set roster. Hawkeye, Scarlet Witch, Thing, Daredevil and Storm were the original starter heroes you could pick from at launch several months ago. I’ve heard from other people that Gazillion has changed this a little and that certain heroes have been added to the starter hero roster, namely Captain America. I can’t confirm this because I already have Cap in my main roster.

Yes Marvel Heroes is free to play, you don’t need to pay for new heroes if you don’t want to… but you will be required to grind fairly hard if you want to unlock your desired hero. A special item called an Eternity Splinter can drop at random at any time during the game when you defeat an enemy, you will need to collect anywhere from 400-600 of these to unlock one hero of your choosing.

Your best bet to play as the hero you want is to actually purchase him or her, the average single hero pack will run you around $20 US currency or less.. There are some benefits to doing this.

-You unlock your favourite hero right away, no grinding for weeks to earn Eternity Splinters.
-You get your heroes STASH tab, this is an extra inventory tab in your shared STASH locker. Stash tabs at the moment cannot be unlocked with Eternity Splinters.
-You get an additional costume or two for your hero. Costumes at the moment cannot be unlocked with Eternity Splinters.

PAY TO WIN:
Yes and No. There is a cash shop in the game where you can buy new heroes, stash tabs, costumes and items such as temporary XP boosters or Retcon devices which reset you’re heroes skill points so you can re-allocate them. The only real advantage a paying player has over a non-paying player at the moment is the XP boosters so they can level up a lot faster and the ability to buy more stash tabs for inventory space. There are usually a fair amount of seasonal sales in the cash shop throughout the year.

HEROES and VILLAINS:
There is a large roster of heroes to choose and play as, like..
Iron Man, Hulk, Ms. Marvel, Captain America, Black Widow, Thor, Cyclops, Wolverine, Jean Grey, Gambit, Emma Frost, Storm, Colossus, Deadpool, Cable, Spider-Man, Rocket Raccoon, Ghost Rider, Luke Cage, Punisher and many more.

Including some upcoming heroes and villains that have been announced for a release in 2014 such as Magneto, Juggernaut and Venom.

Each hero for the most part plays differently than the next and has many different skill trees to put points into as you level up. You can literally have two people playing as Thor with two very different skill tree builds leaving you with two very different play styles.

The basic types of heroes are you standard melee and ranged heroes… and those who are a hybrid of both. Spider-Man is a great example because depending on how you spend his level up points you can build him as a pure melee or pure ranged hero.

VERDICT:
If you loved Marvel: Ultimate Alliance on the Playstation or are a comics fan and loved the Diablo series, then you will feel right at home here. Marvel Heroes continues to get better each month in terms of re-balancing and content being added, this game has come a long ways for a “Free to Play” game in one short year.

It is almost criminal that this game is free to play because it is very fun and addicting, especially if you are willing to pony up the dough and purchase a few of your favourite heroes.

reviewText:
A definite re-review of the game's score is necessary. Being able to fling Squirrels at enemies and seeing them explode makes this game an automatic 8/10. Everything else added on top of that averages out to be about 20/10. A little unfair perhaps? Perhaps you don't judge squirrel flinging as astutely as needed.

The game follows the Diablo format while adding plenty of reasons to actually spend money on it. You can, in theory and practice, play this game for free. So go ahead. Yet, when you want to join in on the squirel chunking antics, go ahead and drop a few dollars on a great experience.

This game is executed better than the new Diablo, but still feels like the design team is missing out on a few things. The UI could use some work and finding your way around feels too chaotic considering their attempt at a flowing narrative. The story seems to follow one straight line, yet they seem to have multiple instances of HUBs and a confusing array of shops and needlessly difficult crafting options. With the amount of loot the enemies drop, you'd assume a better labeling system would allow you to sort and pick better. It doesn't. A simple Green or Red arrow would allow me to see if equipment was better or not. I understand that each bit is entirely unique in some cases, but mostly, the amount of judgements I have to make is a little tiring compared to other titles.

Ignore Metascore and try this game. After you've Hulk Slam'd" and "Squirrelpocalypse'd" a few times
date: then judge for yourself. I have enjoyed it so far."

reviewText: Someone who mainly plays first person shooters and racing games probably isn't the target demographic for an Action RPG, but being a fan of the X-men in the late 80's I figured I'd give it a shot, and boy did this game suck me in.  I got in at launch when the game was pretty rough, which ended up working to my benefit because there wasn't an overwhelming amount of gear slots and crafting stuff in the game yet, but Gazillion has put a ton of work into this game, not just in the past year but consistently every single week.  This game is always growing so you might as well hop in now!  You can play this game completely free if you want or spend money to get access to the heroes/costumes you want right away, it's entirely up to you.  It's free so get some friends to play with and do your best not to stay up until 3 A.M. leveling too high above your friends who went to bed at a reasonable hour.  If you do don't worry, just get another hero and level them back up to where your friends are!

reviewText: Great game, but the producers seem to push out new characters before they are completely ready.  You have to remember this is a business and they will push out content before it's fully ready and fix any major issues after the fact all to earn that extra buck. Oh and the community managers like to delete any type of post they don't agree with and may or may not suspend your account on the forums (not in the actual game) so beware.  I try to avoid the forums because of this and I also feel and others agree wholeheartedly that the community managers like doomsaw are very unprofessional.  That being said, the game is fun and I've played every character available and I finally found one I like and have been doing the prestige process, and fair warning, cosmic is a definite journey (The hero synergy exp bonus is a definite must for cosmic).  Hope to see you in game.

reviewText:
I've played since beta and I do admit i wish i had bought into the founder's pack then.  The game wasn't the greatest but Brevik and team did not give up and the game is worth what i have spent on it.  I bought a large amount of Gs which I have barely spent any.  I'm not a costume guy or feel the need to get every hero soon as they come out.  So the $100 or so I've spent which has kept me occupied for at least 6 months and prevented me from buying a new game has been worth it.

The actual review:  If you're into Diablo and the endless item grind that it is then this game is for you.  The amount of heroes will never end and make this game the most repetitive game ever played.  I do enjoy it as a game that i can pick up and play anytime and there is at least something new be it a hero i have yet to get to or actual content.

Actual content added within the year:
1 Midtown madness an endless instance which isn't the greatest content.
2 x-defense wave like survival mode for 5 players.  Holo sims wave like survival mode for 1-2 players.
3 Omega & Synergy systems that equates to more grinding the same content (account leveling).
4 Enchanting a new crafter
5 Asgard content (thor dark world content)
6 Man ape one shot story (actual content)
7 Muspelheim raid (actual content but hard to get in unless you're part of a large group)

So as you can see as far as actual new content and new stuff to do its very limited.  Compared to releasing 1 hero a month (and now team ups) you can tell where their focus was and continues to be.  This game to me feels like it's still in beta since they still haven't completed the full review of the starting heroes.  But it's on the right track and the next year is/will be exciting with the release of villains and another one shot that's on the list for sure.

reviewText: This game is awesome. If Diablo 3 left you feeling cold, or Path of Exile didn't quite hit the right buttons for you, then there's a good chance that Marvel Heroes will be the game for you. Better yet, you can enjoy the entire thing without spending a dime. The only thing that you can't earn in-game is stash space and certain fortune cards (which are borderline useless anyways, basically scratch-off lottery tickets where 95% of the rewards are terrible).\n\nIt's also a very 'no-pressure' type game. The way the content is set up, you can leave for months at a time and not feel left out. In fact, if you do leave for months, you will come back to a game that is noticeably better than before. This game updates at a breakneck speed. I've never seen a game shoot out so much content so fast. There's maybe like 0.5% of the entire population that can possibly keep up with it all.

reviewText:
Did you enjoy Diablo 2?  Of course you did!
Do you enjoy the Marvel movies that have been bringing us pretty colors, bright lights, loud sounds, and Scarlet Johansson in a skintight catsuit? Of course you do!

Now that we've confirmed those two things let me tell you why Marvel Heroes 2015 is the game you’ve been looking for all your life.
To start with, it’s not Marvel Heroes!  That’s a good thing.  Marvel Heroes was the bottom rung, the last horse out the gate and the farthest from the finish line.  Over the past year Gazillion Entertainment has been turning that withered nag into a proud, polish, thoroughbred of the ARPG community.

If you’re anything like me, you were disappointed with Diablo 3.  Sure it was fun, but it lacked that certain element of chaotic delight that made Diablo 2 an entertainment darling. Well, folks, Marvel Heroes was made by many of the same folks that made Diablo 2 what it is.  This IS the spiritual successor to Diablo 2, with the bright shiny veneer of the Marvel universe lacquered onto it!

Love Spider-man? You can be Spider-man.
Love Wolverine? Well, bub, crack open a cold one cause he’s here too!
Are you heralding the coming of Galactus? Silver Surfer was added to the playable heroes list on June 21st 2014!
More heroes are added every month. If your favorite character isn’t playable now he will be soon!

I know what you’re thinking “But it’s F2P, that means the character I want to be is locked behind a paywall.” WRONG!   Anything you want in this game you CAN get without ever spending a dime, and it doesn’t even take time grinding to make it happen. On average I can unluck a hero every two weeks, just by playing 1 hour of this game a day. That’s 14 hours, that’s one lazy Saturday when you’ve got nothing to do!
If you want it you can achieve it. The only things locked behind a paywall are cosmetic items, and even those have a randomized chance of being unlocked for you through the games crafting system!

Folks, if you love comics, if you love super heroes, if you love good ARPGs, this is the game for YOU! Give it a try. It’s free, it’s fun, and you’ve got nothing to lose but one lazy afternoon!
If you join the legion of fans look me up in game. I’m TheFiveVirtues, representing the Skrull Infiltrators, if you want a fun SG, or just need some help learning the ropes I’ll be happy to help you out!

reviewText:
This free-to-play (!) game has fulfilled my every ARPG expectation that Diablo III failed to live up to. It's just pure explosive smashy-flashy fun, just what I want in my isometric hack-and-slash games. Do not be fooled by the low Metacritic score, this game has been improved vastly since the (admittedly pretty awful) launch.

The F2P model doesn't require you to spend a penny, no content is blocked off and almost everything in the game has a chance to drop. You're not forced into MMO-mode either, unless you feel like teaming up and kicking some villainous butt. It's perfectly possible (with some informed hero/build/gear choices) to solo 95% of the content. PVP is also entirely optional and still in the works, but looking promising.

If (like me) you enjoy your Pretty Princess Dressup and have a bad case of Alt-itis, then you will be hooked by the cosmetic choices and ever-growing roster. The game's sparkly visuals are accompanied by some of the best voice-work I've ever heard in any ARPG or MMO. The Dev team seems to be on the top of their game and really willing to listen to the community, too.

But the most important thing- killing things in this game just feels so satisfying! Juicy punches, smashing jumps, laying waste with fire or hordes of squirrels, confusing a whole screenful of enemies - whatever the ability or style, it just works and feels so damn good. It really grows on you too. Once you get access to your hero's skills and stick with it, combat in other ARPGs feels like hitting stuff with a wet newspaper.

reviewText: When this game first was released many sites I think unfairly gave it a negative score, in no way did it deserve a 5 or below could easily have given the game a 6.5-7. Since release the game has gotten esponentially better. Newcomers get a beter starter hero selection and all heroes can be unlocked with splinter drops, which happen to drop pretty often. Yes costumes still cost money and their drop rate is ridiculously low but Gaz needs this to be their money maker so I have no problem throwing money to them to make my character look how I want.\n\nIf you like ARPG's or the Marvel IP then theres no reason not to try this game. It's free and its fun.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is officially my new sick addiction lol. The game had a rough start with its bizarre F2P model but just about everything has been reworked since then. No longer do you have to pray for a random hero to drop as loot or get the 2 more lame starter heroes from beating the story. With the implementation of Eternity Splinters and Cube Shards you can earn for FREE new Heroes and alternative costumes. You can have hours upon hours (I'm almost to 100 hrs lol) of fun playing this game without ever spending a single cent. I recently did buy $20 bucks of in game currency to buy a STASH box and mostly just to support the Devs that made this fantastic game. Its rich in the lore of Marvel and the X-Men. There are currently 29 playable heroes with each one playing entirely fresh and different from the last one you scrambled through the game with. In 2014 we are getting an additional 12 characters with some being infamous playable Villans such as Venom, Magneto and Juggernaut. Nightcrawler is the next character due out and Ghostrider just became playable so in my honest opinion this is the best time to try this game out or give it another shot if you were unhappy with the model when it was first released. Oh and did I mention Deadpool has an unmasked attire, Hulk can SMASH in a Santa Hat, and Emma Frost can charm enemies into fighting along side her? I'll leave it at that :D

reviewText: Marvel Heroes is essentially Ultimate Alliance 3 with a more Diablo bent. There's a large cast of characters and they're all different.  You have to start with one though, but the game gives you a nice starter roster. I've been playing as Punisher and its been real fun. Other characters cost money or you need to find a certain amount of in-game items to purchase them by beating the campaigns or by enemy drops so you best stick with a character you'll like unless you want to put in the time or money. Really its not a big deal though because the Free to Play elements are well utilized in the sense that you can just casually enjoy the whole game without spending a dime. Definitely worth playing, and because its free you have no reason not to.

reviewText: Superheroes are a weird subject for an ARPG/MMO-lite type game since those tend to be so gear-focused but MH makes it work. The game isn't without its flaws. In transforming it from its previous, universally panned incarnation to the present one, the devs have developed about a billion and a half systems, thrown them at the wall, and seen what sticks.\n\nSome of them are pretty half-baked or make power creep an ugly inevitability. But there's enough genuinely awesome stuff going on that MH mostly succeeds despite itself. And with a zillion characters to play and counting, you're sure to find something that matches your play style.

reviewText:
MH2015 is an a-rpg of sorts. Don't expect your tipical ♥♥♥♥♥♥me here. It's a fun and quick game but not without its drawbacks.

The pros are as follows:
You can play as one of a sizable cast of characters. You get to choose a starter and a second one the next day. You can also earn the rest of the characters via a farming system.
Each of those character has different skills making each one a potentially unique experience.
The maps and enemies are quite fun to play. Things like a a goon saying aww
date:
just get me to the cops already" are quite amusing.

The cons are:
The game is very repetetive. By the time you play your second character you'll know it by heart. The game is limited to only a few maps. This is a shame because every one of these maps has many events and easter eggs which lead you to wanting even more.
The game tries to solve this repetetiveness by every now and then changing the directions of the map
recommended: which is endlessly annoying.\nA lot of farming. If this annoys you
hoursPlayed:
then this is not a game for you.

Final verict.
I had a lot of fun in my time with the game. Many heroes were enjoyable and played well

reviewText:
PROS:
-A huge and ever expanding roster of your favorite Marvel heroes
-All heroes can be obtain through playing the game
-Story mode is a good length and fun to play
-Endgame has improved tremendously since launch
-Constant updates monthly
-New PvP mode
-Fun combat
-Free-to-Play

CONS:
-Game needs solo/group dungeons outside of reusing story mode instances
-No hardcore mode
-No ladder resets

SCORE: 8

THOUGHTS:
Let's get right to it. When the game originally launched back in June of this year the reception wasn't great; okay it was bad. The game gave a bad first impression to new players that didn't participated in the beta. Marvel Heroes has a lot of heroes to choose from (27 heroes and counting) and at launch the only way to obtain more heroes outside of rare drops (which were pretty damn rare) were to buy them with real money. Okay, that doesn't sound to bad right? Wrong. The pricing for the heroes were outrageous at the time, costing upwards of $20+ for some of the premium heroes like Iron Man and Spiderman. This left a bad taste in a lot of peoples' mouths.

But now, this has all changed. Gazillion Entertainment has listen to their community and brought prices down to much more reasonable levels. Top tier heroes will cost about $9 to buy, much better than $20+ dollars back then. There are packs that may cost more but that's up to the individual on if it's worth it to buy. But the best news was how Gazillion added an ingame currency called, Eternity Splinters" that you can farm and use to purchase the hero that you want
date: without paying a dime. This was a welcome and needed change. Now players can get every hero in the game just by playing the game!\n\nSome of the other things that Marvel Heroes had a bad rap about was the combat was boring and there was nothing to do once you beat the game. Well
recommended: Gazillion has been busy reworking heroes and changing visuals and making combat much more exciting this time around. I remember playing Iron Man on launch day and thought to myself that he was kind of weak and dare I say it..boring. But when I came back for update 2.0
hoursPlayed: Iron Man felt like
voteText: well
helpfulPercent: Iron Man and he was so much more fun to play.\n\nThe endgame was lacking as well like I mentioned before and once you beat the game you were either running the same terminals over and over to grind to max level or you were leveling an alt. Gazillion has added much more things to do this time around. Along with your daily terminal runs you can also replay the game in two other difficulties
votesHelpful: Heroic and Superheroic. Or you can farm items and grind levels on huge maps like Midtown Manhattan with other players or play a survival style game in X-Defense where you protect students from the Xavier School from an invasion. Also
votesTotal: a new addition to the game is PvP called
votesFunny: "Fire & Ice"
commentsCount: which is still in beta where it's a 5 vs 5 where you protect your giants and attack other players and their giants onto destroying their base to win the match.\n\nOn top of that
column16: Marvel Heroes is now starting to add more chapters to the game
column17: starting with Chapter 9 in Asgard. In the coming months there will be more additions to Asgard as it expands
column18: for now
column19: we have a small taste of what's to come.\n\nGazillion is doing a tremendous job listening to their players and making changes as quickly as possible to ensure quality. As well
column20: as giving us new content and updates every month. If you played the game when it first came out or are discouraged about its low Metacritic scores
column21: don't be
column22: the game has improved leaps and bounds since then. Gazillion has a determination to make Marvel Heroes the best ARPG ever
column23: you can be sure that greater things lies in store for us in the near future and the best part is that's all free! Give this game a shot (or another shot) and you won't be disappointed."

reviewText: I tried Marvel Heroes when it first launched and thought it was freemium, pay-to-win garbage. I'd heard it had greatly improved over the last 5-6 months and was much better, so I decided to give it another shot. I'm glad I did.\n\nIt's a really fun ARPG with frequent content updates, a sane pay model (all purchasable content is either completely cosmetic [costumes, pets] or also available through playing/grinding), regular events (with bonus XP/loot), and a decent loot/crafting system. Although you're playing on servers with other people and while there is support for groups (and talk of raid content coming in a future update), it also seems to be one of the most solo-friendly ARPGs of recent years -- nice for when you're feeling antisocial and just want to grind some loot. Marvel Heroes can be a little rough around the edges in spots but overall it's a really enjoyable game, regardless of how much or how little money you spend on it.

reviewText: Diablo for comic nerds.  Is there anything better?  It's easy to ignore the flame wars on the social chat by turning it off, but find yourself a good supergroup and you're in like Flynn.  I love the controls, though it is a very click-heavy game (carpal tunnel syndrome will result after too much playing).  The mechanics are fantastic, Gazillion are great with special events and upgrades, and there is continually new content.  For a free-to-play game, they do a fantastic job.  A must have.

reviewText:
Not bothering going into the 'It's Diablo, but with Mavel!' since everyone else can.  Overall, it's a fun time
Pro's:
-It has Unusuals
-It's fun and engaging
-Voice cast is great
-A lot of content

Con's:
-No hats
-Havent taken any of the great features from Torchlight or Diablo (pets can sell stuff, good visual item compare, etc)
-Pay-2-win in some ways (there's this currency that drops in game every 10 minutes or so that you can use to buy characters, costumes, and these crates that contain super buffed weapons - you can buy crates (cards) that drop the currency so you can buy the crates, and basically never worry about fighting anything)
-Horrible grind in other ways (that 10 minutes to get 1 eternity spike when everything costs 40+ spikes is ughhh)
-In-game things aren't explained well (Crafters - why should I give the crafter my items? What do the recipes mean? How much are the items worth to the crafter if I donate them? etc)
-MMO rather than single player with co-op (It's a con for me because I hate people)
-Can't be Agent-X

reviewText:
TLDR: Marvel Heroes is an excellent ARPG, and is well worth the download.

The Good:
-Free to play, and not Pay to Win. You can earn everything in game without cash. Including costumes (however, costumes are extremely time prohibitive to earn, and random besides.)
-Large roster of playable characters, with a new character coming out every month.
-Older characters don't get forgotten, every month an older character also recieves a review pass, ensuring that they're keeping up with the new guys.
-Tons of stuff to do, including pvp, terminal missions, neverending zones with progressive difficulty ramp, story mode, one-shot story lines (side stories not related to the main storyline), numerous items to farm, several collectable currencies, crafting, enchanting, etc.
-Characters often have multiple builds that work efficiently.
-Team Up" sidekick characters with multiple skill paths add variety.
-Constant updates
recommended:
and a willingness to listen to the playerbase.

The Bad
-Story mode gets repetitive
hoursPlayed: however several story quests give permanent bonuses to your character
voteText: forcing you to complete them if you want to max everything out.\n-The fortune card system is just aweful
helpfulPercent:
and needs to be rethought.
-PVP is still in 'beta' and needs a lot of polish.
-The sheer number of Iron Man costumes taking up my stash space.
-Some costumes are just re-colored versions of the original.

The Fugly
-It can get repetitive. Of course

reviewText: Overall this is a really good game.  They have weekly patches that contain events and fixes. New content is added pretty quick compaired to other games.  Crazy amount of heroes to choose from if you pay for them, they can also be aquired in game with currency that drops but it takes 200 - 600 eternity splinters to get (which 1 drops about every 6 minutes). Hero packs are well priced for what items you get with them.  Muptiple costumes for each hero, which is really cool (They can drop but is very rare. Also can be purchased).  This is an ARPG/MMO (Setup similar to Diablo).  The first couple heroes you level will be a bit of a grind, but you really learn how to play the game in that time frame.  I would recommend getting your Crafter and Enchanter leveled up for upgrades as you level. Check this game out if you like ARPG games or MMO style games.  Pick a starter hero for free and try it on!

reviewText:
I play using -nosteam now so I didn't quit on March 11th. I like this game and play it a ton but it definitely has some flaws as an ARPG. It is held aloft by clever use of the Marvel franchise.

ProsGameplay
Free to play.
Wide array of Marvel characters to choose from, new release monthly.
Different types of game modes, up to and including MMO style raids, with varying levels of difficulty" and time commitment.
Flavor! Popular classic and new costumes
recommended: ENHANCED costumes that do things like gender swap
hoursPlayed: character swap
voteText: power color swap
helpfulPercent:
VA swap. Many Team-ups that can tag along with you. A few cool visual effects you can add to your costume.
MMO style build trees with unlimited resets allows some variety in power sets. Plus Omega Point system allowing further stat customization with tons of choices.
Cybernetic pets add a small extra possibility for stat customization along with the ability to "vacuum" (eat) loot off the ground plus the actual pet following you around when summoned.
Design shift towards for easy travel with vehicles
votesHelpful: fast running
votesTotal: flying
votesFunny:
teleporting at low or no resource cost.
Play solo or in a group.Graphics
At max settings there is a nice colorful style taking the middle of the road between gritty realism and cartoony. The dynamic lighting and shadows are quite nice and the motion blur effect is not overdone.
With full effects on this game looks absolutely bonkers. You actually really need to turn them down or you can't even see your own character!
Constantly improving character and costumes design. Many older characters are starting to get reworked looks to be of much higher quality than release.
Audio
Being an official Marvel approved franchise they have some great known VAs and realistic lines for fully voiced heroes
commentsCount: Team-ups

and villains.

Pricing and Misc.
You start out with one free hero and by earning in-game currency you can buy any hero or Team-up of your choice without $.
Through log-in rewards  you are given enough currency to buy a medium priced hero or Team-up and then other things like bonus exp

and even some special pet and Team-up items after 100+ days.

reviewText:
This game, is one of my favourite F2P games I have played for a long long time. Besides Warframe, I enjoy this game HIGHLY, because of this lush enjoyment and it's variety. As a fan of Marvel and Comics in General, I love seeing the references to Marvel's Lore and all sorts of Marvel things, which makes this game the more entertaining.

This game is said to be similar to Diablo III, which I haven't played so I cannot comment. Though I have played for only a short few hours (In game terms, it would be short), I have so far had fun with the Hero I had started to play with, as well as the one who I am currently levelling along side with my Mid 30's Gambit char (I got Gambit, Punisher (Defunct) and Psylocke). That being said, it can be quite a bore just levelling, but then again, this is minor due to the variety this game gives.

A few cons for me would be the Eternity Splinters, the alternative to the Pay To Win route in this game. I admit, I paid for Gambit and Psylocke because both of these characters was a major want for me. But, for something like a Team Up char, I want to use the in game alternative. Why am I complaining? because the spawns are set on a timer and they only ever spawn once every few minutes (Sorry I do not know the specifics) and you can't farm. That's fine, but I really think they should atleast add extra splinters for reasons like increased difficulty boss fights, X-Defense etc.

Another would be some forms of repition, mostly because sometimes the Midtown patrol spawns the same bosses or the same enemies without giving you more challenge. This is minor, because it can be fixed wiht a simple difficulty change from Normal to Heroic (Hard).

Overall, I really enjoy this game, and thats suprising because I never always liked Free To PLay games (AHem. APB. I am looking at you.) and I never liked Pay to Win, but this Pay to Win is a good system.

reviewText:
This game is an innovator. Like anchovies and cherry Jell-O, Marvel Heroes has dared to combine two ingredients that were conventionally kept separate: MMOs and ARPGs (aka Diablo-style games). Any challenge, story, or sense of skillful execution that previously existed in the ARPG genre has been thoughtfully removed from the game, so that the player may enjoy a more pure experience of applying their mouse skills onto a screen that is marvelously flashing.

Nostalgia seekers rejoice! The talent trees in Marvel Heroes have rolled back the clocks on modern MMO talents that focus on important decisions and noticeable changes to gameplay. Instead they embrace the charm and whimsy of early-era talent trees that provide incremental damage increases and minor improvements to existing abilities. Don't worry about needing an abacus to figure out the talent trees though, it's literally almost impossible to make a decision of any sort as you fill in the points.

The challenging and exciting dungeon crawl experience that we all remember from the peak of the MMO era lives on Marvel Heroes. The challenge of coordinating carefully and skillfully with your team mates to overcome incredible odds has been seamlessly replaced with the challenge of racing to keep up with your team as you all swing, slide, teleport, and sprint for the center of the next room. And you'd best master your simple movement ability quickly! You want to get to the next room while enemeis are still standing so you can begin pressing your strongest AOE attack! It makes colors!

While the excitement of hard-earned triumph is only a faint memory, the pulce-pounding thrill we felt as we peeked into a slain monster's treasure horde has been generously shmeared across the entire experience so that it never violently peaks like that again. This leads to a very mellow, constant influx of unexciting rewards. Ideal for today's anxiety-prone gamers.

Take a step away from the pressure of needing to learn complex mechanics" in your game. I don't even know what a carburetor is. Something in bread that makes you fat? Whatever
date: leave the science to the "hardcore" gamers. Sit back
hoursPlayed: and take a stroll with a reasonable approximation of some of your not-quite-favorite "super" "heroes"."

reviewText:
With a huge roster of Marvel superheroes - and after some serious game-improving patches over the last year - this is a Diablo-like fans of the genre wouldn’t want to miss. You pick from a decent handful of starter heroes, like Punisher, Black Widow, Captain America, Colossus or Storm, then go about fighting through a nine-chapter campaign either by yourself or with friends. If you’ve ever played Diablo, Torchlight or other games in the genre, this is exactly like that except a bit more bombastic. Overpowered doesn’t even begin to describe how it all feels, but it fits the topic well.

As you play, an in-game currency drops with regularity which can be used to unlock additional heroes. Or, if you’re impatient, you can buy more heroes with real money. But I’d recommend just saving up the in-game currency for the hero you want, it doesn’t take that long. Once you finish the campaign, you can replay it on increasing difficulty levels for better drops, or hit up a variety of end-game content types like horde-style holo missions. There’s even high-level raids, but those require max-level characters and a firm understanding of how to play.

Before the “2015” patch, I was hesitant to recommend Marvel Heroes to anyone. But to Gazillion’s credit, they’ve overhauled the game dramatically, and now it’s a must-play in my book.
