reviewText:
Mahval Heroes is a Diablo style rpg that you play as various heroes/anti-heroes from the Marval universe. The game underwent a massive rebuild because the old game was boring, and you didnt get to play who you wanted to. As of now you can play all heroes up to Lv 10 and unlock anyone from the start.

Now game play wise I find it to be a very relaxing pick up and play type game, no stressful things like dps gates/hours of required grind. There is alot of variety in the people you can play like Venom who can be a hybrid ranged/melee who is all about regen to Storm who is a walking AoE (Area of Effect) with well storms. Now some heroes are still not up to date to the new current standard of fun but they are being worked on.

The cash shop is fairly standard like League of Legends $10 more or less for heroes and costumes (with exeption of ENHANCED that change model voice lines and ability flavor). Small boost comsumables etc.

Now the game isnt for everyone if you dont like dungeon crawlers for loot this it not for you. If you are concerned about the END GAME there are raids and cosmic trials/danger room that ups the difficulty, two raids currently in game more on the way. If want to feel powerfull kill tons of goons and get loot this may be the game for you

TLDR
Pros -
Most heroes feel strong
Just about everything can be earned in game
Large variety in playable classes
Decent story
For Marval fans lots of fan service between costumes and character interactions

Cons -
Storage Space is a large problem free players dont get that much (This is they only thing they dont give away in spades)
Just starting out everything can be a bit slow
If you have bad RNG it can take a while to get what you want

reviewText:
Do you like ARPGs like Diablo and Path of Exile? Do you like Marvel? If you answered yes to both, you really need to install Marvel Heroes right now.

Strong, solid combat. Very high quality voiceovers. A classic Marvel storyline in the main quests, and all sorts of Marvel villians, tropes, and references abound. The graphics are great, both in effects and tunability. Animations are fun to look at, fun to execute with.

In the current state of the game, it thrives on repetition just like other ARPGs. Marvel Heroes throws enough uniqueness into the mix to keep gameplay from going stale. At the time of this review, you have 36 superheroes (and counting!) to play. No two heroes play the exact same. There are a ton of choices and I'm sure that anyone can find a favorite or two out of the mix. Every gameplay style you'd want in an ARPG is here. You can boil the abilities down to simple types (single target spirit spender") but they'll all have different effects
recommended: different synergies with the hero's passives and gear
hoursPlayed:
etc.

The game is receiving constant updates. The developers are on top of the community at all times and have a very active presence on their forums. The game developers are making it clear that everything in the game is verified and allowed by Marvel.

To touch on the free-to-play aspects; you don't have to spend a single cent. The cash shop consists of heroes

reviewText:
More 'maybe' than no. Read on to find what I mean by that.

**EDITED INTRO 11/15/2015*
Originally I rated this game a 'Yes', but now I definitely lean more towards no. Maybe my tastes have changed. maybe I've simply beat the game too many times. Maybe I haven't given the 'endgame' a decent try (I really haven't). but whatever the reason, I don't feel like playing this game anymore. :(
**

(NOTE: this is more 'what you need to know about Marvel Heroes' than a review.
It includes tips, info, & me explaining features of the game. If you want in-depth pros & cons, there are other reviews for that. thanks.)

Marvel Heroes MIGHT be worth you checking out. I have 'played' this game for 415 hours so far, but I have a hard time recommending it unless you...
1. like...marvel's heroes A LOT &
2. have a friend or 2 that will play it with you sometimes.
3. have means/money you can add to your Steam account when the time comes

Basically it's a fun Action-RPG BASED ON BEING (A) CERTAIN CHARACTER(S).
IF you enjoy being said character & don't care too much about level design or story, then you will enjoy this for its gameplay and FEELING LIKE said character(s).

but you have to have really good self control. The game rewards you with Eternity Splinters that let you buy/unlock more characters. The main negative is you will be tempted to buy a lot of things with real money (in currency called 'G') -especially more STASH- OR you will constantly have to clear out your storage spaces (which is what I do all the time always, even though as-of this review, I have 9 STASH's +3 character-specific STASH's). The upside is they are constantly updating it, adding playable characters, events, team-ups, etc.

key features to know:
BODYSLIDE: this is a teleport that takes you back to a HUB at any time. It has a cooldown of 10 minutes. It can be used twice before the cooldown starts: once to take you to the hub and once to take you back (to the spot you bodyslid from).

ULTIMATE: every character has an Ultimate power/skill. To my knowledge, they all unlock at Lvl 52 (max lvl is 60). The cooldown for the ultimate starts at 10 minutes (but you can put points into it to be less).

key TIPS to know:

you have to LEVEL YOUR CRAFTER (by donating items to it): this is just a tip, but it's an annoying thing considering much of the early game you are left wishing your crafter was a higher level, but all the crafter is really good for IMO is tranfering an item over to another character. And also for upgrading blue gear to purple.

You get a LOT of LOOT: So plan accordingly. Until you get a 2nd stash, I wouldn't even think of getting a 2nd character, but that's just my advice. Once you get a 2nd STASH, then you can start another character, maybe even 2 if you can handle limited storage.

but there are a LOT of different items in this game, including artifacts, costume cores, 'crafting items' (4 different types with 8 different tiers for each), boost potions, pets, rings, runes (used in crafting with URU gear), URU gear (1 wearable per character, can't wear until Lvl 25), medals, medallions, and a few more I can't think of now.

*update1 [05/13/2015]* - I feel I should mention the cost of things in this game
*update2 [06/18/2015]* added in 'crafting tab'  to pricing list below, & its price/value/usefulness
*update3 [07/04/2015]* added introduction to try to better explain my goal of this 'review.'

PRICING
STASH (regular) : 500 G ($5.00)
Character-specific STASH : 350 G ($3.50)
Crafting Tab: 200 G ($2.00)
^The first 2 are the main 2 tabs you should ever 'NEED' to buy in this game.
I recently realized how valuable crafting tabs are later in the game, since I had a TON of runestones and crafting items that can be stashed there. I didn't know Runes (aka. runestones) were allowed in that stash, but NOW that I do, I think they are a good deal if you have 4 or more rows of runes sitting around (that you don't want to get rid of).

That said, MH only lets you buy Gs in 'bundles', otherwise known as lump sums.

There is 500 G bundle, 1000 G bundle, 2100 G bundle ($20), and so on.
This is an annoying model and I dislike it very much, but what can you do about it?
The only thing I will say in DEFENSE of this model is the fact that it's KIND-OF like a subscription fee...only you actually get something in return, and if you look at it that way, it's not so bad. Especially since you are NOT forced to pay anything to play this game.
---------
TL; DR = if you have a friend playing this with you, & you like a marvel hero a lot, try it.

....if you have no money to buy anything, you probably DON'T want to try it, because you will be muy (very) frustrated.

reviewText:
Pros:
- The wide variety of characters and costumes that you can buy are actually decently-made enough to worth the money, sometimes.

- The powers are varied and feel like their comic book counterparts, not half-♥♥♥, which is more than I could say for other superhero games.

- You could unlock numerous characters very easily (I think they might unlock heroes for you when you buy one of their characters). I only have one character left that I need to unlock after ONLY purchasing Spidey, which is Ant-Man.

- The story is well-written enough to look and feel like a Marvel comic book, and the aspect of fighting the wide variety of villains from the comics brings back that immersion we had from Marvel Ultimate Alliance. The quest-lines are well-written and immersive enough for Marvel fans that you won't realize most of them involve the simplistic action of mob-killing.

- This is probably the only Marvel video game out there that doesn't 'juvenilize' the stories the way LEGO and Disney Infinity did with their games. DOOM will not crack stupid, nonsensical jokes for the most parts, and characters will act like their serious counterparts from the comics.

- Opportunities for future epic storyline to be tied into the game, stuff like the upcoming Civil War movie (god, I hope they make you choose a side) and maybe even The Infinity War.

- Christopher Daniel Barnes voices your Spider-Man when you buy the '90s 'Amazing' costume. Nostalgia galore. The developers at least know enough of what the fans like to create such fanservice.

- Daily rewards when you log in encourages you to return to the game.

Cons:
- Kill-steals. You will not bother to do a lot of side quests because of this, as their requirements rely on event-bosses that you WILL miss because they are all the way at the other end of the city, and by the time you reach there, other players would have killed off that boss and you would have to wait 5 minutes for him to respawn. This isn't essentially a problem if you remember where the boss respawns, but not only do some bosses respawn at different places (Green Goblin in the Lower East Side mission), the kill-stealing also becomes a problem when your quest-requirements involve destroying items like statues. If you're a low level character without an AOE power of some kind, have fun watching Iron Man stealing all your statue-kills with his lasers. Gazillion needs to fix this, as it sucks out the fun for newbies like me who want to enjoy the entirety of the story without skipping annoyances like this.

- Some costumes are terrible, and you can't change it unless you buy a new one.

- The community isn't as toxic as the LoL or CoD community, thankfully, but it's rather difficult to form groups or socialize with the people there. It kinda reminds me of those forums where everyone's doing their own thing and ignore each other's existence. It's not very friendly or helpful, so you'll mostly be wandering around confused if you're a newb to this game and especially if you're a newb to MMO. Almost every MMO has this problem, right? Not really. GW2 has a lot of helpful and friendly people willing to step out to help others. Even WoW has people like this.

- Crafting sucks. It's boring as heck due to the awkward design. Instead of combining your elements" together with ease
date: you'll have to combine click on them one at a time thrice
hoursPlayed: and then click on "take all". It doesn't seem much

reviewText:
I would like to recommend this game to any superheroes fans!

Lets talk about the BAD things first:
The game is laggy, it has memory leak issue after playing 2~3 hours and you may need to re-login, and this issue havnt been fix for a long time, at the same time they are keep releasing new heroes, new costume, random item box in the cash shop.  Thats the most BAD feeling to me.

For the GOOD side:
Tons of heroes to play with, they will constantly review on heroes' skill and re-desgin for better gameplay experenice. Also this game has quite large amount of contents, after finishing Story, you can continue on harder level, go to an open map for killing enemies or boss hunt,  enjoy wave defend with your friends, etc.

How FREE is it:
I think that the costume and EXP/item drop boost are their main source of income.  If you dont brother about costume, the stash space is the only thing that will cost you money.  Heroes can be obtain using in-game item, but it takes time to collect.  Remember to check for the promo code, they gift players items very often.

reviewText: This game is FANTASTIC! The level of love and dedication by the developers is unlike anything I have ever experienced in a MMO. Patches happen every single week and range from bug fixes to new content and costumes. New characters come out every month always leading to new experiences and game play options as well as the game has a steady turn out of new in game modes and content form Raids to midtown with many options from multiplayer to enjoyable single play. It also has the best online community I have ever seen in a MMO and I am very proud to say I am a member of this community as well as the fact that my love for it has lead me to become a streamer. I am the type of person who never sticks with a MMO (often because of the community) and rarely level caps more than one or two characters. I have been playing MH since beta (and the game has improved VASTLY)  and have many level caps as well as several characters I have prestiged multiple times. This game has earned my love and I can see myself playing it for the next 10 years without getting bored <3

reviewText:
This game is amazing for a f2p game. I want to start off by saying that thereis alot of hype about having to buy the characters you want to play with. You are able to unlock every character through rare drop ingame without having to pay. The characters range anywhere from 6$,9$, & 12$. Ironman, spiderman and deadpool are 20$ which i think is due to how popular they are. I will agree that the costumes are overpriced starting anywhere from 6$ to 20$.

The gamplay aspect of the game is amazing. If you are a fan of Diablo 1 & 2 you will have no problem falling in love with this game. The characters look stunning as do the abundence of costumes. There is bosses everywhere and they are very tough at times. There is plenty of skills to build and they work fluidly.'

All in all this is a must play f2p game for comic fans and arpg fans. I spent 10$ ingame and dont feel robbed. The graphics are good, the characters look amazing, the fan is friendly and helpful. There is a deep lore for players not fimiliar with the Marvel Universe. Best F2P game ive played in awhile!

reviewText: Mechanically, this game is basically Diablo 2 with superheroes. Simple, clean ARPG controls that any veteran of the genre will pick up in 2 seconds flat, and all the loot ever. No, more loot than that.\n\nOne great thing is that unlike many superhero games, this one you start right offf feeling pretty super, you're not sitting there going 3 enemies
date: can I handle this?" you're going "MOAR BADDIES!" and charging headlong in to everything because you think you can win.\n\nThere's a ton of heroes to choose from
recommended:
each with its own strengths and weaknesses. I've yet to find one who wasn't fun.

The downside to this game is the business side:
You start with 1 free hero
hoursPlayed: and get the credits to get a 2nd one on your second day playing. After that though you have to farm an in-game currency for 30-90 hours (roughly) depending on the hero you want
voteText: or spend 5-15 bucks on single hero.\nIf you want a costume beyond the base one for each hero
helpfulPercent:
be prepared to drop $7+ per costume.
If you want a larger stash? $5 to add a new tab. Or $3.50 to add a item-type specific tab instead.
Want a hero to help you out? $3+

Got a random free hero that you don't want? Too bad. Already have it? Have a point for their ultimate. Costume you already have
votesHelpful: don't want
votesTotal: or don't have the hero for? Too bad. There's no player trading of heroes or costumes.. Or most of the in-game resources.\n\nThe game is a lot of fun and worth dropping some money on

reviewText:
Though I've not played for too long, Marvel Heroes 2015 is an Action RPG with former developers of Diablo, such as David Brevik.

At first, the game may seem extremely monetised, though Heroes are now purchasable with a currency gained from gameplay, which drops every 6-8 minutes, these heroes can range from 200-600 of these, but you can purchase a random hero box for 175. Failing that, the game also sells heroes in prices from $4.50-$13.50. It may seem much, but games such as PlanetSide 2 get away with charging $2 for a decal, $10 for a hat, $10 for a SINGLE weapon (in which they could have up to 3 of them), which could get expensive for the several classes it runs. In Marvel Heroes, each hero is being balanced constantly with 52 reviews, and is much more different than the previous.

You're given access to a choice of 11 starter heroes, which is about a third of the roster, and these aren't filtered by strength of character, as both top-tier and bottom-tier characters are littered among them, though you'll get 200 splinters (the currency for buying characters and other stuff that you could get with actual money, such as Team-Up heroes, which are passive-granters OR a companion with inventory space similar to diablo) for completing the story (defeating green goblin & doctor doom)

To reach 60, you can reach it in several different ways, though it's unfortunate that it's usually the constant grinding of Legendary Quests, which are quests where you either backtrack through previous story missions on tougher difficulties or finish terminals by killing X amount of enemies, destroying a certain amount of an object and also defeating the boss of that terminal. These terminals are in 3 difficulties, with 12 of them in each tier, each difficulty giving even better loot. Other ways to level include X-Defense and Holosim, which are wave-based in killing as many enemies as you can in Holosim, though X-Defense is defeating a set amount of enemies and bosses while protecting several AI (an escort mission without any movement). There's also Midtown Manhattan, which is scattered with enemies and bosses which spawn every so often, which is usually the ideal way to get loot. For the end-game, there's cosmic terminals (the toughest difficulty) and green raids (red raids coming soon! at the time of August), which require much gear to be completed well.

However, one problem with the game is you've got a limited amount of space, you have 30 slots for your Teamup Hero (which you get regardless if you own the teamup), 48 stash spaces, as well as an inventory the size of 60, this will quickly fill up unless you purchase one of the stash spaces (which come with hero packs on the steam store or ingame OR purchased indiviually), which not required can be a royal pain in the ♥♥♥ when you're trying to gather up unique-tier items to trade in for credits/relics/any hero uniques.

Every week, there is an event that uses a currency, while also boosting the XP, rare and special item find (that boosts the find of drops such as Splinters, the event currency as well as loot), these events are recurring, such as ARMOR Incursion event, Cosmic Worldstones, Omega Access Files and the Midtown Madness, where only Midtown lacks an event currency for unique items, but instead boosts the Midtown drop rates to an INSANE RATE, which managed to get my character Gambit geared out in less than an hour.

There's a selection of over 35 heroes, with more coming every single month, with most of your favourite Marvel Heroes and even some Villians (read: 'Anti-Heroes'), though these are most likely to absolutely be a pain to keep up with if you don't have money and want heroes that are already out.

One major issue also is that the game is artificially extended, with some recipes having an astronomical price and some loot items, as well as 'Droppable costumes' (which seem to be a once in a lifetime experience) taking forever to drop, the game can be an absolute grind to acquire all of the items needed to be adequate during the endgame, as well as some characters being downright terrible (Ghost Rider) or boring (Cyclops), though these characters will get a buff and some changes to add a signature move, as well as a bosskiller and improved Ultimate.

I'd rate this game 77/100, though it's not even half as bad as some F2P games on steam, but has some severe graphical issues for some people including memory leaks during LONG sessions of gameplay.

reviewText: I came into this game with absolutely zero expecations. My past experience with F2P games hasn't been the best, but I figured I'd give Marvel Heroes 2015 a shot since I'm a big fan of Action RPG games. At first, I wasn't very sure about this game... but the more I played it the more I liked it. It's got everything you'd expect from a full fledged MMO, and it feels like playing Diablo (only with Marvel characters). The depth of this game will surprise you.\n\nAfter having played 3-4 chapters through the storyline, I was completely hooked. I remember thinking I'm gonna spend a lot of money on this." Which is exactly what I did. And I don't regret it! Where some games feel like they're just made to milk you for money
date: Marvel Heroes 2015 is simply an enjoyable game deserving of some recognition and support. They ask for absolutely nothing

reviewText: Game is 10x better now than at release. The eternity splinters is a MUCH better way to farm for new heroes than the previous. Especially when you factor in that they had it set for a higher drop chance of the current hero you were playing, solely for an upgraded ultimate. The ONLY thing I can really downvote this game for is the fact that EVERY hero shares the same inventory. I know it is because the game is F2P and they have to make money somehow, but Path of Exile is F2P and they don't share the same inventory. It is a hindrance unless you PURCHASE more stash space. I haven't had to yet, but I am sure at some point I will so that I can stop just trashing gear. But in the end I quite enjoy the game for its combat and theme.

reviewText: When I first came to this game in the open beta, I was pretty underwhelmed with it. Coming to see it a year later, it still failed to grab my attention. Today, with the release of MH2015, I find myself juicing this game into a full glass of simple fun. It is a simple level and loot grinder, the kind of you expect from people who made Diablo.\nThe game has a couple problems, though. It lacks visual customisation apart from expensive costumes for each hero. Said costumes are too expensive, costing almost as much as regular heroes, though, to be fair, each costume allows you to apply upgrades, so it's not pure visuals. Hero team-ups, again, cost at leastr as much as lower-tier heroes, while being basically a useful pet. And the worst offense, or lack, of this game is...it has you play as a pre-set character. The roster is decent and growing steadily, but it is no Champions Online, where you get to create your very own, original superhero, complete with stories, a nemezis (or several), even powersets.\nAll in all, however, Marvel Heroes 2015 does a great job being a free-to-play MMO action-RPG. Has a ton of loot for each hero, weekly event and grindzones, decent story and allows you to play as some of your favourite characters from Marvel comics.

reviewText:
+A ton of characters to choose from
+They constantly make new events to keep the game fresh
+There's a lot of players on all the time
+The community has been pleasant to interact with for me
+A ton of different costumes, although certain characters are lacking
+Game is being updated all the time

-Holy smokes my wallet.  This game is extremely expensive to play if you want to have all the heroes and a lot of costumes.
-To get heroes or costumes and also to level your character, get omega points, eternity splinters, etc  is annoyingly grindy to the point where you'll want to just buy them (just like mobile games).
-Some heroes are extremely similar in playstyle.
-Balance of characters is quite off. Some are much, much stronger than others.

Overall: I've definitely had fun with the game as I love action RPGs and super heroes.  I would rate the game a 6/10 as of Aug. 13, 2015.  If the game wasn't an insane rip off to buy characters, costumes, team ups, etc I would give it an 8/10.  I had a good amount of expendable income before, so I've paid over $500.  That's just to get characters, costumes, stash spots, and team ups.  Even paying that much I still am missing characters, 70% of costumes, and over half the team-ups.

reviewText: This game is FANTASTIC! The level of love and dedication by the developers is unlike anything I have ever experienced in a MMO. Patches happen every single week and range from bug fixes to new content and costumes. New characters come out every month always leading to new experiences and game play options as well as the game has a steady turn out of new in game modes and content form Raids to midtown with many options from multiplayer to enjoyable single play. I am the type of person who never sticks with a MMO (often because of the community) and rarely level caps more than one or two characters. I have been playing MH since beta (and the game has improved VASTLY)  and have many level caps as well as several characters I have prestiged multiple times. This game has earned my love and I can see myself playing it for the next 10 years without getting bored <3

reviewText:
My Ratings:

Action: 5/5
(Re) Playability: 5/5
Story: 3/5 (above average for an MMO)
Graphics: 4/5
Community: 5/5
Just how free is it? 4 out of 5

Let's assume that you are looking at this game for the first time. Maybe you heard about it from a friend or are just perusing steam and thinking about trying a new game. Whatever the reason, I think this game has evolved exceptionally from its initial release and reviews. Since it is an online game with many many players, you will see people that complain. That is the nature of the world we live in. I have personally enjoyed the progression this game has made and feel that it is quickly approaching an established and refreshing place in the MMO space... and all that aside, it's just plain fun.

Here are the top 5 reasons to play this game:

1. Free. It's free. It doesn't have any hidden charges or the need to spend money to play or get the best characters or items. The more you play, the more rewards you get IN-GAME. That said, time is considered by many to be money. So if you don't have time, you won't be getting a lot of stuff by playing. But... if you don't have time... you probably shouldn't be playing games anyway :)

2. You used to play diablo 2 online and want a modern interpretation of that. This game is a better implementation of a multiplayer action rpg than diablo 3. I'm sorry to say it because I loved diablo 3... but I have not touched it in several months because of this game.

3. You enjoy both solo and coop play. Sometimes you want to be the lone wolf, sometimes you want to play with a few friends or strangers... Marvel Heroes has both options. Best part about this flexibility is that if you are ever struggling, just hop on the social or LFG channel and you will probably find someone to help you in under a minute. Sometimes, under 5 seconds.

4. You like playing games with lots of action. Most of the time, everything on the screen is getting blasted, punched, stomped upon, lasered and/or blown up. If you are looking for a quiet game of chess, go play a quiet game of chess. This is about action.

5. Flexible play time. Play for 5 minutes, play for 12 hours... the choice is yours and both are viable options. This is radically different than other MMOs where they purposely make you travel for 10 minutes before you get to your actual gameplay.



Here are a few warnings just so you know what you're getting into:
- The character you pick when you start is the one you will play with until you have enough Eternity Splinters to buy a new character (in-game)
- Sales happen so if you are considering spending real money on anything, you might want to consider waiting for a sale.
- I am a PVE player that has tried PVP. If you are looking for world-changing PVP, this might not be ready for you yet. Their PVP arena is intense but there is only one option that I know of. They are definitely working on it though, so maybe try the game out and see how it develops.

reviewText: Ok if you love Marvel Comics and want to feel like u are actually playing your favorite hero this game is great. If you are willing to grind a bit you can get evreything u want in this game for free minus skins which in my opinion are kinda pointless unless you absolutely can not stand the way the base skin looks for some reason and also extra stash slots which are nice but not completely necessary. So all the reviews about the company who makes the game money grubbing are pointless to me at least. I have almost 20 char at max level and have only spent 10 dollars on this game and that was for 2 char and a stash box and some other goodies when they were on sale. In other words i have gotten 600 plus hours of gaming for 10 dollars and could have had that for free if i didnt want the extra inventory and a char BOGO sale purchase. Is there some things that could be improved upon? Most certainly. I agree with the reviews that state that some new levels need to be added. They keep pumping out new characters which is great and all as i love many different marvel characters and enjoy playing them. I love  getting to use their powers and building them to my liking as far as the skills and powers go but it is getting a litttle old as it is the same levels and fights again and again since their has not been any new story added. So they only real difference  Character to character is the fact that the skills and powers are unique and the dialogue which in itself is entertaining and very true to each character. If you are not a die hard Marvel Comics fan you may not enjoy  the little things as much as i have though. i suggest give it a try as it is free and you lose nothing unless you choose to buy something. In which case if you are selective about what you buy and when it still is not a waste of money as far as i am concerned.

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cSpIdTGnER0

Imagine Diablo 2 or 3 in a Marvel Universe!  Marvel Heroes 2015 is the Marvel MMO ARPG that you have been waiting for! Play as Iron Man, Star-Lord, Thor, Wolverine, Hulk, Spider-Man, Captain America and many more as they team up to try and stop Doctor Doom from devastating the world with the power of the Cosmic Cube. Marvel Heroes 2015 features a deep leveling system unique to each Super Hero, diverse locations set across the expansive Marvel Universe, a robust crafting system, action-packed player-versus-player (PvP) and much more. Marvel Heroes is a free-to-play Massively Multiplayer Action RPG for PC created by David Brevik, the visionary behind Diablo and Diablo 2 with an extensive original story crafted by Marvel super-scribe Brian Michael Bendis. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
First off, this is, at its core, a very good action RPG. There are a ton of heroes to play, boatloads of different attacks and abilities, a vast array of items both functional and cosmetic, and for a free to play game, it is pretty unobtrusive. You don't really have to pay much if anything to get a lot out of it. It's very colorful, has a sense of humor, and delivers mostly satisfying action. If you're really into comics (I'm not) I'm sure it's doubly interesting. Me, I just like the goofy over the top lootsplosioins and tossing cars at people.

That being said, oy, the bugs. Even a brief search on the web will show that many, many people over the past two years have reported, and continue to report, crash bugs, both those that crash only the game and those that blue screen your PC. Most of them involve some sort of error messages about missing files that Unreal's debug routines reports. Often, these involve .dlls like, um, the windows kernel and various directX thingamajigs. I mention these because even on a brand new installation of windows, with hardly anything else on it, the game crashes routinely. These crashes transcend processor type, GPU type, OS, memory configuration, whatever. They've been going on for months if not years and Gazillion seems no closer to either fixing them or even communicating to anyone about them.

Add to this the ongoing glitched quests, unresponsive clickable objects/portals, items that won't equip properly, UI displays that don't update with the correct stats based on changing items, and all of that, and yeah, you have a seriously wonky game at times. It's a tribute to how essentially sound the concept is, and much of the execution even, that I even continue playing the damn thing. But the crashing and glitches are, to say the least, annoying. And even though the game is free to play, most everyone who plays for more than a few hours will put in a few bucks, if only for stash space and stuff like that. Once you put money in, your concern about bugs starts to get more intense, you might say.

Anyhow, if you like Diablo III or Path of Excile or Grim Dawn type games, but want something faster, more gaudy, goofier, and over the top, this is a good place to find those things. It's not as polished as Blizzard's game (duh), nor is it as intricate as PoE, but it does what it sets out to do very well, and entertainingly.

If it just didn't have so damn many bugs....
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I have seen negative reviews of this game when it first released.
One night I was bored, and decided to dig in to Marvel Heroes.

I am glad I did, and even though it is years later. That may be the best thing. Now they have a preview option for the characters before perming your choice. I had lag in one instance, however upon going to another it was cured within the same game. The beatem up linear style is usually something I am against. But due to the MMO style fan base where you can see others, and have them help you along your journey makes it even more entertaining allowing it to go above passable.

The loot system to me is a bit complex, but I played MMO's when Warcraft was first releasing so I may be out of my league until I get more up to snuff which I am sure will happen easily with time. That isn't a fault on the system, just me failing to easily become familier with it in a quick amount of time.

The end game seems decent enough, I have yet to achieve it due to the level cap and how long it takes to reach it with a single character. However I hear very good things, and if that isn't your flavor you can always swap characters trying a new one out.

One downside as with most Free to Play titles, is after you choose your character. You only get one character, that you can fully level up. With out putting in some good amount of time, or money you will be stuck to this character. So make sure you choose wisely and test each one to ensure your good experience.

Path of Exile with Marvel. That is what it feels like to me, maybe even a bit simplified which isn't a bad thing.
Best game I have seen Free To Play wise, and with a controller it is a fun way to spend some hours messing around at the very least. I would give this game a try even for casual beat em up fans, that have some what of a back ground in being a Marvel fan. Because the Marvel cosmetic really keeps the game fresh to another extent. At least it does for me.

reviewText: 9/10\nThis is not your usual shoot 'em up Marvel game. First off, let's start with the heroes. This game has a myriad of different heroes, and it's a guarantee you can find your favourite one in this game. Every hero is well balance, making the playing field even, yet at the same time still allowing you to feel like your hero can do what he was meant to do. Hulk is still a walking tank, Wolverine is still a close combat menace, and Deadpool still excels at shooting, slicing, and most importantly, talking. As for the story, my honest opinion would be that it is sub-par at best, with many logic flaws, and the fact that your hero is most likely not even in the cut-scenes is a huge immersion breaker. The game-play on the other hand, is amazing. For a free to play game, this game is NOT pay to win in anyways. It's not too much of a grind if you want to get your favourite hero, if it isn't even in the tons of free available starters in the first place. And if you want to unlock a hero that isn't a starter instantly, you can just buy it. It's a tad pricey(About US$10-US$15), but for the hours you'll put into it, it's well worth the money. The controls are very easy to master, and the combat system is simple yet effective. The fact that the graphics are amazing and yet can run smoothly on my laptop is a bonus. What's more, much of the map is destructable! If you're a fan of MMORPGs and Marvel, this game is a must have!

reviewText:
I just finished the story mode, this is the most face rolling game I've ever played. I really want to like this game, and I sort of do, but everything about the actual gameplay is just a substandard Diablo with a lot of free to play hooks.

The characters are very well done and look great, but when you get a bunch of them together in a boss fight, it's just chaos with all the powers flying around, apparently things get harder in the 10 man raiding content, that is the sort of stuff I'm normally interested in, but positioning is extremely irritating the way this game controls with m+kb I really think I'd hate raiding in this game.

edit: it's been a week since I finished and I'm still playing daily and enjoying it.

I was really disappointed that this is an mmo where you can't create your own custom character. You need to chose from a hero already existing so everyone" runs around looking the same. On top of that there were no easy way to track your party members from all others on the minimap (a diffrent colour or something would have been good. We got lost from eachother all the time.

Other then that the game is pretty fun. I don't really understand why it is realeasd as an mmo as it doesn't have alot of mmo features in it but its a fun diablo/torchlight kindof gamestyle.

You can buy almost everything from ingame currency and there are not much restrictions for free players so it's a really a good free to play game. Unlocking more then one character with just ingame currency takes some time though and that is really sad as in ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes you are use to be able to have more then one character especially so you can play one yourself and one with your friends for example.

Try it out and see for yourself if this is a gamestyle for you. I will probably stick to the others superheros mmos that are out there but that is only a personal taste of mine."

reviewText: I think this game did a pretty decent job at bringing together all our favourite Marvel Super Heroes plus Villians, into 1 single integrated gaming experience. I could not have asked for more for a Free-2-Play title. Content wise might be lacking in some areas, I believe the team could do a better job at releasing content add-ons in future. However, the game mechanics and customization of your heroes would have compensated for the game play hours. Overall, I love this game as much as I loved Diablo II/III and Torchlight I/II!

reviewText: It would take a long time to go into all the things this game does right. The short of it is Marvel Heroes 2015 is the new 'season' of Marvel Heroes, which launched as a catastrophe of a game and somehow, against all odds, did a complete 180 turn into one of the most amazing MMOs, and hands down the most successful MMORPG, in a long time. Tons of characters to choose from, tons of modes, absolutely beautiful and intense graphics and battles, new features and constant updates, and the most interactive and transparent development team I've ever known. Hands down, also one of the best, if not the best, F2P styles ever.\n\nI honestly don't know how Gazillion does it. They've hired some real gems to run this game and it shows. It makes sense that one of the best game development teams out there could make one of the best games.

reviewText:
Where to begin?  Let's face a year ago this game was so so, taking a page from games like Diablo Gazillion gave us a simple game that a year ago was somewhat fun.  Yeah it was cool that you got to play as many of the popular Marvel characters and interact with one another and traverse in famous locations seen in the comics.  But the game wasn't anything spectacular.  Fast forward to now and you have yourself a good quality product.

With the amount of updates this game has had and introducing new content, new characters Marvel Heroes is a much better game than what it was when it launched.  I find tons of fun playing this and playing as multiple heroes.  This game is 100% free.  Your given a good selection of heroes to pick from and can get more either by spending some cash or collection what's called eternity splinters and trading them in for a new hero.

If your a Marvel Comics fan then I recommend you give this a game a shot.

reviewText: If you enjoy the idea of being a Marvel hero and beating up bad guys from Doc Ock to Loki, this is the game for you! It has an interesting campaign, which you can repeat three times per hero, if that is your thing. Each hero has a set of powers and trees you can set up as you see fit (based on level and rewards). So if you want to Hulk Smash! you can (though he will take some time or money to get).\n\nAbout once a month they release a new hero for purchase, some of which are villains that occasionally have worked with heroes in the comics. Which can lead to interesting instances, like Juggernaut facing Juggernaut in a boss battle. Interactions between characters can also be fun. For instance, Black Widow entering the room to fight Doc Ock and saying something to the effect that the Doc of all people should know to fear spiders. or Loki looking at Deadpool (another player character) and wondering if he was a lunatic or a visionary.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Addicting as hell.

There's dozens of heroes to play, and each of them has lots of interaction with the other heroes (Deadpool being the best one probably), which is really neat if you know the Marvel universe, unfortunately though there isn't really much content, you basically just level up heroes to the cap and/or farm instances over and over to get rare loot (wait, that's basically what this genre is about...).
They try to distract you throwing events at your face every other week (there's like 4 or 5 that keep rotating), and add new batches of heroes every couple months, which can be nice.
Being F2P you don't have access to everything right away, the content is free for all but to get new heroes you have to play a lot and get these coins" that allows you to get new heroes. You can get a new one every week or so if you play about 2-3 hours a day. Inventory space is very limited and shared between all your heroes (it will drive you insane after a while).
Also bugs. Not really game-breaking
hoursPlayed: you can play as a naughty psylocke so 10/10"

The hero will also comment on other heroes. i do not trust you" or "Finally a worthy apponent" are examples my heroes have said while in a hub with other players.

Marvel Heroes is an MMO with a nice community. Yes there are trolls

reviewText:
I've logged over 300 hours playing Marvel Heroes and I can say in all honesty that this is a great game.

When Marvel Heroes was released in mid 2013 it quite rightly took a lot of flak as it really wasn't as good as it could've been but over time Marvel Heroes has become a great game. The development team care about the game, the player-base and also the IP. Free-to-play" games tend to have a nasty sigma attached to them - cash grabs or pay to win. Well in Marvel Heroes none of that is true. All the heroes that you would like to play can be obtained from just playing the game. None of the heroes are gimped in anyway and all feature an exciting set of powers.

When you start you can choose from nine different heroes. Characters such as Human Torch
date: Storm and Scarlet Witch. Other characters which can be unlocked include classic Marvel characters such as Spiderman
recommended: Thor and Hulk along with some of the more out there heroes like Rocket Raccoon and Squirel Girl.\n\nCurrently there are 31 playable heroes with more released each month - Invisible Women
hoursPlayed: Pyslocke and Reed Richards are the next scheduled heroes to be released.\n\nA good story mode
voteText: decent end-game content and PvP (exiting beta soon) all combine to make a great game.\n\nNow
helpfulPercent: as with many free-to-play games there is a premium currency - but you do not need to spend any of your hard earned cash. Sure
votesHelpful: you can purchase heroes and costumes should you desire but you do not need to. Marvel Heroes has been designed to allow total and full access to all content for free.\n\nIf you enjoy Diablo
votesTotal: Torchlight or other Action RPG games then you will enjoy Marvel Heroes. It's free so download it and try it
votesFunny: you've got nothing to lose have you?"

reviewText:
In a nutshell, this is Diablo, but with Marvel superheroes. My review in a nutshell: it's a free game, so download it and take it for a spin. It's really, really fun in the short term, but likely not in the long term.

I found out about this game around the time I was looking for an alternative to Diablo III, which was plagued by both frustrating, unbalanced difficulty and (worse yet) a hostile and arrogant developer base that constantly found new and fresh ways to nerf players. When Marvel Heroes launched, it pretty much had the same issues, with numerous bugs on top of that, but eventually the lead developer stepped into the forums and told us they were going to overhaul the game. And they were wildly successful. Comparing the game at launch to the game at the end of 2013 is like comparing a dying firefly to the sun.

2014 saw Doomsaw, the lead developer, begin reneging on his anti-nerf stance[i.imgur.com] and, worse, begin underhandedly silencing anyone who voiced their opinions against him[i.imgur.com]. The people in that compiled screenshot were far from disrespectful and it became clear Doomsaw was basically going on a power trip. Doomsaw's philosophy is to make heroes with high damage output but really terrible survivability. An example is when people pointed out that melee heroes couldn't survive a boss affix that summoned high-damage area-of-effect around them, whereas ranged heroes could just run away and still attack. The developers' response was to implement the Missile Reflect affix because clearly, the problem wasn't that melee survivability was in the toilet; the problem was that ranged heroes were surviving too much.

The second thing really hindering this game is its lack of longevity. The main draw is to level new heroes, which is great if you've got a particular hero you want to play as, but after a couple of iterations of (1) complete the story 3 times, (2) level up using legendary quests, and (3) hunt for gear, the game becomes stale really fast. I leveled 13 heroes and the only thing keeping me going was that I have an OCD-level aversion toward leaving something unfinished. Don't get me wrong – new heroes come out frequently and their artwork and powers are absolutely superb, but this doesn't really give the game longevity.

The game's free, and the first hero or 2 is amazingly fun. Download it, play through the story, and experience the different modes (Midtown Patrol is my favorite one). You'll have a blast for a month or two. Avoid the forums, and move on afterwards.

reviewText:
Marvel Heroes 2015; A New Life In Store For You[/h1]

The BEST Online Multiplayer Game In History![/b]
I found this game in the store, looking through the description, videos, pictures, etc, and I was not impressed. But later, as I slowly am growing more of a Marvel fan and wanting to look more into the story, I always found a funny feeling that struck me after I watched a Marvel movie.

What, is it like, to be an Avenger, or part of the X-men, or anything else?

What does it feel like to be a hero?

So I looked at this game again after putting it away for who knows how long, and I thought, hey after all, I am looking for a new game, might as well just give it a try. Trying to ignore the fact that it took 13GB of my space on my computer to play, I downloaded it, created an account, and got started.
I chose a starter hero(Cyclops) to start the game, went through the whole beginning process, unlocked more heroes(Captain America by accident, Iron Man, Star Lord), stuck with Star Lord, and I played the whole game with Star Lord constantly upgrading him, soon making him impenetrable, and I have to say, it felt, absolutely, amazing!
It felt so great, the feeling of half-immortality, power, and the interesting things I can do to enemies. It was just a great, never-ending, action packed time. I NEVER got bored. The story may be long, the beginning may be a bit boring, but when you reach the  Avengers Tower to start the real journey, inspiration and excitement just fills you. So soon enough, I completed the storyline, defeated the immortal" Dr. Doom

reviewText:
Listed as a F2P and really, you can get anything gameplay related for free with the appropriate time investment, but you'll quickly (a few days, definitely before maxing your first character) find that limited inventory space and the massive amount of character customization, and therefore crafting items and equipment, prevent you from playing cost-free. Gameplay-wise, MH2015 is very similar to Diablo or any other isometric adventure game with the biggest difference being that the game is set in the licensed Marvel Universe. So you can see Black Widow in her Avengers movie costume running around, Rogue in her classic outfit fromt he 90s cartoon, and many more. Like all of the other games of this genre, end game is about grinding all unique gear and equipment to get as strong as possible. If that's not enough, and you're a glutton for punishment, you can 'prestige' your character by leveling them up to lvl 60 again with an exp gain handicap for a fancy color name. Not enough of a grind? Do it AGAIN with an even bigger handicap for a different color name. Yeeeeeah... that's not for me, so instead I'm more interested in outfitting a few characters.

Without bonuses from buying in bulk or deals, G (in-game $ currency) is 1-$0.01, so another storage page is 500G = $5.00. You can buy up to 19 more for a total of 20 storage pages. There are cheaper storage pages for specific things. You can get up to 6 pages that can store only crafting items for 300G, of which you'll likely want at least 2 because 1 of each Rune Word will take an entire storage page alone. You can also buy character specific storage pages which are essentially for storing alternate gear for 350G. Items stored on these pages have to have been worn and bound to the character. And of course, the game will give you 250G which is just barely not enough to afford any storage to help nudge you into that first purchase. If you like the game and want to play a lot without throwing all your items out, you will likely spend at least 1600G on storage alone for 2 pages of crafting and 2 pages of storage.

If you know exactly what you are looking for and don't keep any spare equipment/ items, you could get by with 1 storage (48), character inventory (60), and team-up inventory (30). This will probably keep you from trying to equip multiple characters a time and saving alternate equipment to switch builds but it's probably possible if you insist on remaining F2P. Of course there are some restricted costumes that you can only obtain by paying $ for, but all characters can be obtained with in-game currency without spending $. All content is open and access is unrestricted. But man, that inventory cap is just killer and is really the biggest push to make you spend $.

reviewText: Marvel Heroes is one of those Free to Play MMOs that you can acquire anything for free by just playing the game, Spending money does not give a significant advantage. With that said, I've spent a decent amount of hours on this game and I'm still not bored of it. There are plenty of playable characters, missions, dungeons, raids, pvp and objectives for you to do all the time. The game is also updated regularly and new characters are released very fast.\n\nMarvel Heroes is very warm welcoming to new players, there are plenty of tutorials and the quests are VERY informative(they straight up tell you where to go). The community is also very active, there is VERY little toxicity and everyone is quite nice and will happily lend you a hand in information and even enchanting materials. I'd recommend this game to any Marvel fan or diablo style superhero loot game fan. Atleast give it a try come on....its free.

reviewText:
A few years ago when I first played this game, I would of given it a negative review, but a lot of my old complaints seem to have been answered in my leave from playing it.

So I'll begin this by listing some of my old complaints for those of you who played this a few years ago.

1.Unlocking heroes was a pain.
Back when I first started on this game, heroes would only be unlockable by one way prior to your first pick, and that was extrmely rare drops.
Those drops also tended to be one of the same few heroes you got to pick from the start (The thing, scarlet witch, Hawkeye, from what I remember)
None of the A-list heroes people would love to play, and the rest were behind a pay wall.

NOW however, you can pick almost any hero you want to start as, and you can test any hero up to level 10 before you are required to pick which one to unlock.
Enemies how have a chance to drop eternity splinters as well, which can be use to buy heroes.


2.Bugs bugs and more bugs.
some of the only screenshots I ever took of this game in the past were of bugs and glitches in the game.
Mobs refusing to die and glitching out in place, bosses glitching out off screen, ragdolls turning into mangled horrors, screen tearing, ect ect ect.

So far, as I've come back to the game I have noticed almost none of this (aside from one ragdoll going nuts while stuck in a door)
The game seems to run great and I've only had the game bug out once so far.


3. The game was way too freaking easy.
Everything about this game when I first played it felt like a joke, I face smashed through the first 3 major areas of the game and had not one single moment where I felt like I might die.
In fact, the hardest boss I ever fought was 3 bosses (king pin, elektra, and bullseye)


Sadly, the game still feels super easy on the normal mode, but now once you pass up normal mode it does feel a lot more satisfying on the harder modes, which you can only unlock after beating the game (prior to the new added last boss).
The first 30 levels still feel like sort of a breeze, but it's not so bad that you just feel bored luckily.



Over all, this is a great dungeon crawl type game, with a decent crafting and upgrade system, and fun satisfying characters and abilities.
The voice acting and little interactions between characters is also entertaining, and now that picking your first character is more hands on and open, you wont suffer from seeing 900 copies of IT'S CLOBBERIN TIME!" on the screen
recommended: very worth it for a free to play title
hoursPlayed: and if you grow attached to a character
voteText: consider a skin.\n"

reviewText: This is by far my favorite game on steam. Even when I take a break for a few weeks I always find myself coming back to Marvel Heroes. 99% of everything found in the cash shop can be aquired through time spend in game. That being said it can be a huge time sync. Only spending ~50 hours in game is not going to get you to experience the best of what this game has to offer. Raids and other end game activities will require you to actively grind for better and better equipment and omega points. But with a new hero released every month, almost constant events, and new game modes being added several times a year, Gaz does a great job of keeping the game interesting.

reviewText:
Great game - The game is free to play yet has store and item shop that isn't so annoying to make you quit as some games tend to do.  I like the game overall yet could use some more interesting mechanics to make it more fun after 50-100 hours or so of game play it may get boring.

You can change heroes which will keep you from getting to bored.  They give you a nice methods to buy new heroes with money and without money to keep you playing.  I am still hooked so far 300+ hrs.

If you like the Diablo style games you might enjoy this. The devs enjoy adding new heroes every few months since marvel is a bottomless well of heroes.  There is new single player content every few months during the year too which is a good way to keep the game fresh.

reviewText: Marvel Heroes is one of those Free to Play MMOs that you can acquire anything for free by just playing the game, Spending money does not give a significant advantage. With that said, I've spent a decent amount of hours on this game and I'm still not bored of it. There are plenty of playable characters, missions, dungeons, raids, pvp and objectives for you to do all the time. The game is also updated regularly and new characters are released very fast.\n\nMarvel Heroes is very warm welcoming to new players, there are plenty of tutorials and the quests are VERY informative(they straight up tell you where to go). The community is also very active, there is VERY little toxicity and everyone is quite nice and will happily lend you a hand in information and even enchanting materials. I'd recommend this game to any Marvel fan or diablo style superhero loot game fan. Atleast give it a try come on....its free.

reviewText:
A few years ago when I first played this game, I would of given it a negative review, but a lot of my old complaints seem to have been answered in my leave from playing it.

So I'll begin this by listing some of my old complaints for those of you who played this a few years ago.

1.Unlocking heroes was a pain.
Back when I first started on this game, heroes would only be unlockable by one way prior to your first pick, and that was extrmely rare drops.
Those drops also tended to be one of the same few heroes you got to pick from the start (The thing, scarlet witch, Hawkeye, from what I remember)
None of the A-list heroes people would love to play, and the rest were behind a pay wall.

NOW however, you can pick almost any hero you want to start as, and you can test any hero up to level 10 before you are required to pick which one to unlock.
Enemies how have a chance to drop eternity splinters as well, which can be use to buy heroes.


2.Bugs bugs and more bugs.
some of the only screenshots I ever took of this game in the past were of bugs and glitches in the game.
Mobs refusing to die and glitching out in place, bosses glitching out off screen, ragdolls turning into mangled horrors, screen tearing, ect ect ect.

So far, as I've come back to the game I have noticed almost none of this (aside from one ragdoll going nuts while stuck in a door)
The game seems to run great and I've only had the game bug out once so far.


3. The game was way too freaking easy.
Everything about this game when I first played it felt like a joke, I face smashed through the first 3 major areas of the game and had not one single moment where I felt like I might die.
In fact, the hardest boss I ever fought was 3 bosses (king pin, elektra, and bullseye)


Sadly, the game still feels super easy on the normal mode, but now once you pass up normal mode it does feel a lot more satisfying on the harder modes, which you can only unlock after beating the game (prior to the new added last boss).
The first 30 levels still feel like sort of a breeze, but it's not so bad that you just feel bored luckily.



Over all, this is a great dungeon crawl type game, with a decent crafting and upgrade system, and fun satisfying characters and abilities.
The voice acting and little interactions between characters is also entertaining, and now that picking your first character is more hands on and open, you wont suffer from seeing 900 copies of IT'S CLOBBERIN TIME!" on the screen
recommended: very worth it for a free to play title
hoursPlayed: and if you grow attached to a character
voteText: consider a skin.\n"

reviewText: This is by far my favorite game on steam. Even when I take a break for a few weeks I always find myself coming back to Marvel Heroes. 99% of everything found in the cash shop can be aquired through time spend in game. That being said it can be a huge time sync. Only spending ~50 hours in game is not going to get you to experience the best of what this game has to offer. Raids and other end game activities will require you to actively grind for better and better equipment and omega points. But with a new hero released every month, almost constant events, and new game modes being added several times a year, Gaz does a great job of keeping the game interesting.

reviewText:
I've sunk quite a few hours, and quite a lot of money into this game.  I find the gameplay to be addicting and fun, every hero plays differently.  There's some overlap, big tanky guys like Colossus, Thing, and Hulk have similarities in powers but there's enough different in each of their trees to keep them feeling fun.  To me it's very much a social experience, I'm in a great guild with lots of fun folks so it makes the content grind a lot easier to bear.

If you're a fan of Diabloesque games, or Marvel comics in general I'd suggest giving this one a try.  There's plenty to spend your money on, but you can get just about everyting for free in game.  Eternity Splinters are an in-game currency that drop every eight minutes or so.  You buy new heroes with them.  The prices range from 200, 400, and 600.  Or what most newer folks opt to do is spend 175 on a random hero box.  Which as the name implies, can give you any hero on the roster at random.

New costumes can be obtained by a sort of costume blender at the crafter.  Three of any costume gets you any random one.  The prestige system grants you a copy of your starter costume everytime you use it, so if you prestige all six times, that's two shots at the blender alone.

The game isn't for everyone.  When you hit the max level it gets pretty grindy, and if you're not into that then you won't have a lot of fun doing the end game stuff.  The first raid is pretty cool though, and they have new ones on the way.  They release a new hero every month or so, and have new game and story content coming all the time.  Not as often as the heroes but it's just enough to keep a lot of folks interested.

reviewText: This is a top quality ARPG/MMO.  Designed by the man behind Diablo 2, even plays a bit like that amazing classic, but with Marvel Heroes, and a few anti heroes (Loki, Dr. Doom, Taskmaster).  It is incredibly fun to play, and with all the heroes available the replayability is great.  The developers are amazing, they listen to the players, and try to implement any suggestions.  They are constantly upgrading, adding content, new heroes, pets, and team-ups.  The community of players are the best I have encountered in gaming, new players aren't put down, or berated for asking questions.  There are giveaways on the forums done by the players all the time for in game items, as well as store items.  These are all things that one would expect from a top tier pay to buy, and play game.  But, this game is free to download, and free to play!!!  You can test any but the most recent heroes up to level 10, then decide which one you want to unlock to max level.  You can buy heroes, etc from the in game, or website store, but all heroes, and team ups can be unlocked for free with an in-game currency called Eternity Splinters, which are drops.  Really the only major thing you have to buy with real cash is extra storage, or S.T.A.S.H., though there are rumors that they may be available for purchase with the Eternity Splinters in the future.  Anyway, I highly recommend this game, and joining the official forums if you do start playing.

reviewText:
-This review is very out of date, and the game is a lot better now. Try it!-

This is surprisingly a good Diablo clone.

The obvious negative about this game is it's free-to-play model, and the fact that you only get one character (to start with.) If you pick someone you don't like, too bad. A period at the start where you could try them out first for a map each, or something like that, would help offset this. The 20 dollar price tag for most of the other characters is really steep, as well.

Still, the actual gameplay and things are done very well in my opinion. The maps have the normal story missions, as well as little events that can pop up. You can just dog pile these, without having to worry about grouping with the other players. You can collect these rare shards that drop to purchase characters as well, but the number required is a little ridiculous.

Overall, it's a good game that is worth checking out if Diablo, Torchlight, and other games in this genre are your kind of thing.

reviewText:
I'm absolutely blown away by this game.

It's free to play and a game that is not pay to win, at all. From the market you can get costumes and new characters, but nothing to give you an in game edge (other than items that boost your item finding and XP rates--but that's not gamebreaking IMO.) I've played a lot of Diablo 3 and Path of Exile lately, but this game by far in my opinion surpasses both of them in both. There are like twenty marvel superheroes to choose from. Each one is unique and specific--they stand out. It's like a they created a unique diablo class for every character. There are multiple game modes and the story-mode is so awesome--to me it feels like you're playing in a Marvel comic. The loot system is intelligent, giving you loot thats more specific to your character. Crafting is amazing. If you find a good piece at lower grade, you can easily craft it into an epic (purple) item for just a small amount of materials.

They're adding new playable characters and content all the time. There's several game modes, so it never gets stale and you're not stuck repeating the story over and over again! I don't normally toot so much about a game, but I'm just blown away. I think I finally found my game--after months and months of searching. Anyways, check it out. You have nothing to lose other than some disk space and you can always free it up if you dislike it.

reviewText: Marvel Heroes 2015 is a free to play action role-playing game set in the Marvel universe and features a huge selection of characters.  The game is a watered down Pay to win" in that additional storage space has to paid for and is a must have
date: which may put off some players
recommended: but there is plenty of content and plenty of fun to be had without spending a penny.  However spending a moderate amount of money (about $19) to purchase enough storage to accomodate a crafting materials storage tab and two additional general tabs should be enough to cater for most players needs.  Essentially a game of this size
hoursPlayed: scope and quality should sell for about $40
voteText: so spending some cash is a nice way to thank the developers and the publisher.\n\nThe player is given a selection of ten starting heroes which can all be leveled to level 10.  In the free to play side of the game the player has an option to unlock one of the heroes (after reaching level 10) enabling leveling to level 60.  Additional characters can be unlocked using in-game currency (eternity splinters which have a drop rate of one splinter every eight to ten minutes) which will take many hours to grind in-game
helpfulPercent:
or players can purchase game currency from the in-game store for real world American Dollars.  The most efficient way to unlock heroes is to purchase random hero boxes which cost 175 eternity splinters each.  Playing an average of four hours a day most players will be able to unlock one random hero a week.

Gameplay is fast and fun with a seamless and smooth massively multiplayer drop-in drop-out mechanic.

Graphics is in full HD (1920 x 1080p) and the artwork is true to the original Marvel comics and animated TV series and spin-offs.  Voice acting is well done and the Super Hero quick witted edgy comments make the marvel universe feel alive.

Gameplay bears similarity to titles like Syndicate/Syndicate Wars and Diablo 3.  Viewpoint is isometric 3-D and the user interface is well designed and easy to use and navigate.  There are a good selection of customizable game settings.

The design is open-world and quests can be either accepted from quest givers or discovered by exploration.  There is a linear story mode with animated cut scenes and voice-overs but players are free to explore and grind levels elsewhere if they so choose.

Players can sell excess items to vendors for credits
votesHelpful: or can donate the items to the crafter or the enchanter to level their abilities and unlock crafting or enchanting recipes respectively.\n\nPlayers will meet many of the villains and experience a variety of locations.  The world is huge
votesTotal:
possibly even massive with plenty of small corners and hidden pathways and back alleys to explore.

Overall a competent time waster that is free to play but will reward players who are prepared to dig into their back pockets.  There is plenty of fun and enjoyment to be had regardless of whether you play for free or pay to progress faster.

7.7 / 10"

reviewText:
Product received for free

I've been playing this game off and on since Beta, and it's one that I've grown to be very happy with. Marvel Heroes 2016 is not the Marvel Heroes that was released straight out of Beta. When I first played it I wasn't sure if I really liked it. I would have given it mediocre at best. But as it stands today with the amount of content it offers, this is quite possibly the best Free-to-Play game on the market - especially if you're an ARPG fan as I am.

Yes, I said Free-to-Play and NOT Pay-to-win. Just about everything (if not all) in Marvel Heroes is attainable in some form or another without needing spend a single dime. But I do admit it can be time consuming, and if you're hoping to get a specific costume for free then pray to RNGesus. I put money into the game because it's a game that I love and believe deserves it. The only thing I still don't agree with are the costume prices, but at least they have no bearing on gameplay or how well you perform.

I've played just about all the current ARPG games out now and Marvel Heroes is still my favourite. It offers a cast of characters that I love, gameplay that is really addicting and fun, and varied modes that keeps it refreshing. At some point I'm sure I'll wander off to play something else, but I know I'll eventually be back for more.

reviewText:
Vastly improved since launch, Marvel Heroes has gone from being a disaster of a game, to being possibly the most generous free to play title available. It helps that they also made it ridiculously entertaining and fun to play.

Once you pick your first hero from the list of Captain America, Punisher, Black Panther, Storm, Colossus, Hawkeye, Black Widow, Human Torch, and Luke Cage, you are thrown into the midst of things pretty quickly. There's a decent amount of in-game instruction, and the community is surprisingly friendly and (usually) willing to help out if you have any questions, a far cry from the norm in a F2P game. Before long, you'll be hunting down D-list supervillians, hunting for new loot, and working your way through your hero's skill tree.

Because each hero has a completely unique skill tree, and by extension, power set, they can each be thought of as an individual class in a traditional Action RPG. Instead of a Paladin, Archer, and Barbarian, you've got Iron Man, Deadpool, and Rocket Raccoon.

Nearly every week, an event is going on that offers some sort of bonus. It might be double experience, it might be increased drop rates, it could be as simple as getting a random item when you log in. The in game currency used to purchase new heroes, Eternity Splinters, drop at least once every 5 minutes. I've sat there and timed it. It's like clockwork. You could save up 175 and get a random hero, or save up either 200, 400, or 600 for the specific hero you want. The only thing you can only get with actual money is more storage space, and given the quality of this game, you'll be needing it.

If I haven't convinced you to try it out yet, maybe this will. David Brevik is the lead on the game. Brevik worked on a game called Diablo 2.

Marvel Heroes is awesome.

reviewText:
If you are an action RPG and Marvel Universe fan then you should check this game. The work and progress done by the developers since launch has made this game completely different from what it was when it first began. The effort put to bring this game where it stands now is attributed to both the developers and the amazing community this game has. Forums are an active pool of information, which should be checked occasionally, since the developers are very active there, providing information, asking for feedback and spoiling things - content which is to come.

The game is free to play, although this genre is perceived differently to each individual. The game is definitely not pay to win since there is no way to pay cash in order to obtain some sort of unique gear which puts you on top of other players who don't spend real money. Most items sold through the cash shop offer comfort throughout your playing experience (more stash space, xp boosts, costumes to alter your heros appearance etc.).

Moreover, your get to pick and play heroes (and even some anti-heroes) from an ever increasing hero roster.

Overall the game has very good depth and offers quite the excitement and is worth trying. You should keep in mind though that the game is following a weekly patch schedule with non stop updates, bugfixes etc. The developers are moving with babysteps into improving this game so some things are not added to the game immediately.


Pros
A free to play Marvel superhero game
Fast paced with depth and many things to do
Many different game modes and more new ones to be added in due time
Amazing community and communication - interaction with the developer team
Weekly patches with small/big changes and events
Almost every month, a new hero to play
Heroes, Team - Ups (followers who add special bonuses to your hero, assist in combat etc) are also purchasable with in-game currency called Eternity Splinter.
XP and minor stat synergies(whih are account wide) gained through leveling heroes

Cons
Occasionally on some zones the game suffers from memory leaks (can be fixed with a quick relog)
If you decide to spend cash on the game, it is a bit expensive
RNG can be painful sometimes
Ultimate Upgrade mechanism is against the current philosophy of the game which encourages you to level many heroes

Finally the game holds some sort of veteran system through two (2) modes (this is a personal view). These are the daily login rewards and the omega system. Login everyday to receive a small reward which can help you through your gaming experience and finally as you progress with lvling heroes you obtain omega points. New players will find themselves behind veteran ones as they start with zero omega points.
