reviewText: Nice game. Just like Diablo, but with iron man.:)
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
It's worth a try because it's free and alot of fun. There are other things than the main quests to undertake such as wave modes in the shield HQ and you can repeat alot of previously completed missions and some new unique ones, on higher difficulties for chances of good loot, like the rifts in Diablo 3.

I didn't try PVP but everyone so far is saying it's a broken mess.

The gameplay has alot of comedy to it, for instance, I had a few items with reflects damage on them while playing as Iron Man and I zoomed in up close and watched as a bunch of mafia dudes fired their guns and the bullets bounced back at them and killed them. So funny watching a bunch of mafia goons with baseball bats KO themselves out by hitting iron man.

It's also funny picking up trash cans and launching them at people.

But, after the novelty has ended you're basically left with a Diablo clone, it becomes all about the numbers you inflict when you press your buttons and the game is nowhere near as polished as Diablo. Despite being free, if you want to quickly have access to the heroes you want to play, you'll have to pay money for them. You can maybe once every few days afford a free unlock token but it's for a random hero. The actual hero tokens are more expensive and take a long time to farm with the ingame currency.

The game also swamps you with items, many different kinds of items and expects you to get your head around all of it. For example you have these things that drop that you need to craft items and they stack up very quickly, requiring that you sit around in HQ transforming them into the more valuable variants for long periods of time or your inventory will fill up quickly. The game gives you one or two inventory slots for free when you start and you get like 4 for free as you approach level 60. This is not enough. The game also gives you cases of gear, with epic legendary items that you can't use yet, so you're left with this overwhelming amount of items just flooding out of your pockets and guess what? It costs money to unlock additional inventory spaces.

This ruined the game for me, alot of people love the opportunity to manage loot but whatever happened to just dollars and basic stuff like that? There are different forms of currencies and all these multitudes of items and tokens and in the end it just left me feeling burdened by it.

Neverwinter had the similar problem, where I was faced with Gold, Astral Diamonds, tokens of this, tokens of that, these gems, those gems, all these different other things to screw around with, half of which costing real money to obtain, when the real successful games have One form of currency and maybe some elite tokens you need to farm to get uber gear. Games like EverQuest, you had platinum aaaaand that's it. World of Warcraft you have gold aaaand that's it. Any other forms of gear progression are introduced to you slowly at the correct time for when you need to know about it. In WoW, enter a battleground? You find out you earn Honor points, and these are what you need for the gear (at least it used to be when I played) that helps you kill people and survive better in PvP. In Neverwinter? You're swamped with many different kinds of currency and tokens from level one.

It's exactly the same with this game. The sheer amount of stuff it just throws in your face is too much and that's why for this game I award the score of:

Standing in s**t at your birthday party / 10


Yeah you're having a decent amount of fun as you're punching people around, roasting people as Cyclops or leaping around smashing stuff as The Hulk, but there is just too much gimmick here, too much cheese, not enough polish and a large amount of poop on your foot

reviewText:
You can feel the spirit of the old Diablo in this game. Mobs spawn fast enough to prove a challenge for everyone, the storyline is decent and you can unlock almost every hero with a lot of patience, if you don't want to spend money. Even a pet can be bought via In-Game currency, so basically the only thing you would want to buy are costumes - if you depend on cosmetical gimmicks, that is.
The overall balancing is rather good, though ranged Heroes tend to have a certain edge over those who rely strongly on melee.

For a play-for-free-title this game is pretty awesome.

reviewText:
Marvel Heroes is developed by Gazillion, a studio founded by David Brevik who's the creator of Diablo 1 & 2. So if your a fan of those games then you should definitely check this title out. It's free to play so there's no excuse. It's a typical ARPG with roots in Diablo. You have a huge roster of heroes to choose from, there are skill trees for each hero, and you have gear to farm for. The game consists of nine acts, with three seperate difficulties. You also have what's called terminals that offer a variety of different modes such as X-defense which is a survival style gameplay, Midtown Manhattan is a endless beat em up, group challenges, solo challenges, and finally PvP. With more modes to come!

It's a solid game with a good F2P model and the development of this game has come a long way. Both Marvel Heroes and Gazillion continue to improve dramatically.

TL:DR - Play this game, it's like crack cocaine with super heroes.

I grew up with Marvel, I read the comics, watched the shows, and debated in YouTube comments about who would win a fight against. I've fantasized about a game like this, where you can run around as your favorite characters doing the ♥♥♥♥ that they did in the comics so this game is pretty much a dream come true for me. This does not however, mean it's free of problems. In order of how annoying these problems are with 1. being the most hair pulling:

1. ♥♥♥♥ not spawning- this is particulary annoying if you're trying to level up your character as quickly as you can. There are these things called Legendary Quests that you unlock at level 20 which are basically 1-3 things the game wants you to do with certain restrictions. Some of the times, the game will want you to kill X amount of a certain enemies in a certain place, or clear Y amount of Treasure Rooms (instances). The maps are randomally generated so you won't know where the enemies or Treasure Rooms are before starting the quest. Occasionally, the game will bug out and either not spawn enough enemies for you to kill, or simply not spawn the Treasure Room at all. reviewText:
My opinions on this game are coming from a fan of X-Men Legends and Marvel Ultimate Alliance. I started playing Marvel Heroes during beta and it was in pretty bad shape. I had a lot of hopes for this game because what could be better than everyone's favorite Marvel characters in a arpg? In the begining it was awful.

The game has changed since then adding in a lot of requested features and there is a weekly patch that usually adds in some quality of life changes or a new weekly event. As in any arpg there is a siginificant grind to the game, so if you are a gamer who hates that I would stear clear. I personally enjoy it to a degree and there are other activites to entertain you to break up the gear grind ranging from the story to terminals to one shot stories and raids.

The only real complaint I have about the game is that since it is free to play some of the most requested items and costumes (which are for vanity purposes only) are often locked behind cash items called fortune cards. These cards are a gamble as the most requested items are a rare drop from these cards and are affected by a random number generator, I have no problem with a company creating a free to play game and selling vanity items, hell I've spent my fair share of money on this game, but it really bothers me that the most requested costumes and items are not for actual sale. We have to gamble to get them and because of the RNG the cost can be incredibly inflated.

Overall the game mechanics are great. Best arpg since Diablo II in my opinion and the closest game we will get to another X-Men Legends or Marvel Ultimate Alliance for the foreseable future. The downsides are the gear grind if you hate doing that sort of thing and some vanity items being locked behind a RNG. I give it a 8/10.

reviewText:
Surprisingly Addictive
----------------------
Marvel Heroes 2015 has become a new addition to my gaming library. As an avid rpg fan I was happy to find another game to add to my arsenal. I've only played the game for just under a month and can definately say it is worth the investment in both time and small amounts  of money.

After playing DC Universe Online, I had low expectations for another super hero mmo rpg; 'pay to win' comes to mind. However, it is fairly difficult for an rpg to be pay to win. You play the game in your own time and enjoy it more as you progress, this review will focus on the Leveling aspect of the game, seeing as you will need to do this 88 times (88 heroes at the time of writing this review.)

Your first 20 levels will be your easiest and can be accomplished in under 15 minutes on some Heroes. However, once you hit level 20 leveling becomes a lot more tedious. You will be introduced to Legendary Quests, this is what you will be doing all the way to level 60. My first character took just under a week to level (playing for 2-3 hours a day) and it became a tedious chore to push through the last few levels. Never the less, it does become easier; the more heroes you have at 60 the more boosts you will receive both experience and stat wise. Keep in mind there are many factors to take into account when grinding. Some players have reported taking only 4 hours to level a hero from 1-60, utilising bonus experience boosts, hero synergy and server-wide boosts. Overrall, leveling isn't as bad as in some rpg games.

This game is heavily grind based but is some-what surprisingly addictive despite the end-less hours spent killing mobs and bosses. Each time you reach 60 you want to play a new hero however, although all the heroes are available to you up till level 10, you feel an enhanced sense of relief when you 'uncap' a hero, even if they don't sound exciting initially. I have uncapped 4 heroes at the time of writing this guide and can comfortabley say I enjoyed levelling each of them, mainly due to each of them having a unique skillset.

The end game content is still heavily grind based in the sense that you're trying to obtain the best items in the game, but once you've achieved this on one character you have 88* more to look forward to.

This game is certainly not pay to win, nor pay to enjoy, but I do recommend buying heroes when there is a particular special or sale like 'buy one get one free' as the more heroes you have the more you will enjoy the game.

Overrall, I give Marvel Heroes 2015 a 7.5/10.

*at the time of writing this guide

reviewText:
After seeing that I've just eclipsed 250 hours, I figured I should probably write a review.

The game is good, it's fun, there's a lot to do, and if you're a fan of Marvel or ARPG's, you'll most likely love it.

It does have some negatives, such as a lack of variety in endgame content and very little customization of your character visually, but they're slowly adding more and more costumes, introducing new systems to diversify your character from others as far as skills go, and it's constantly getting updated.

I've spent roughly $40 this year on the game, and I don't regret it at all.

These devs actually listen to their community!

Long story short, I absolutely recommend the game. One of the few Free-to-play games that do it right.

reviewText:
A true Action RPG that really emphasises on the action part.

The good:
Fluent, fast-paced gameplay with great visuals for powers (skills).
Good voice acting that brings characters to life.
Wide variety of heroes to choose from with regular additions to the rooster.
Leveling up is addicting.
Rotating events for added incentives (like different drops for special vendor items etc)
Supportive community, including frequent developer responses.
Weekly patches.
Big loot explosions.
Occasionally free stuff in the form of game codes offered by the devs.
Overall good F2P model where almost all content can be aquired through just playing the game without spending anything.


The bad:
No randomized areas, like for example an end-game map system (think Path of Exile or Rifts in Diablo 3) which results in very repetitive gameplay. Apparently such a game mode is being added at some point in the future though.
Timed drops, boosting item find" through "potions" has almost no effect.
Every new patch introduces new bugs as well
date: QA is almost non-existant even though a test realm does exist.\nIf you're outside of the US you will often get a very high ping resulting in lags during peak times.\nUnbalanced heroes
recommended: power creep....new heroes feel overpowered compared to old ones.\nUninspiring loot
hoursPlayed: a lot of filler items. Almost every character has the same BIS (best-in-slot) items
voteText: random uniques are almost always useless compared to hero-uniques.\nUnoptimized game areas can result in frame drops

regardless of your setup.


Be prepared to spend some money for stash if you plan to play more than just 2-3 heroes as you will need it

reviewText:
This will be a short and concise review, if you are looking for an in depth look at the game and it's mechanics this is not the review for you. Marvel Heroes 2015 was made by some of the creators of Diablo 2, one of the best hack and slash RPG's ever made, and they don't disapoint with this entry.

PROS
-Extremely fair free to play system that puts other free to play systems to shame
-Vast selection of heroes from iconic Marvel characters such as Spider Man and Hulk to smaller lesser knowns such as Squirrel Girl (not kidding)
-Each hero plays differently from eachother and gives you incentive to keep playing so you can unlock that next hero for a completely different game.
-Classic hack and slash gameplay with tons of loot to keep you playing for hours even after you hit max level so you can the best of the best gear.
-Amazingly incorporates MMO features into the game without losing the feel of the classic hack and slash. Adding things such as raids for you and a group of friends to tackle for the best loot.
-The Co-Op on this game is great, and each player gets their own loot so there is no ninja looting
-The graphics are top notch for a game of this genre.
-Varied Environments ensure you don't get bored with the scenery.
-Constant updates ensuring fun events and balanced gameplay.

CONS
-Variable framerate even on strong computers, most likely due to the MMO-like features.
-Storyline is nothing to write home about, and cutscenes are done in still comic frames with voice overs.
-A few of the heroes need tweaks because they are underpowered or overpowered. (Likely will be patched quickly)
-Very addictive gameplay. This could be a negative for you if you don't want to get sucked in to a game.

FINAL VERDICT
-This game is a strong 9.5/10 if you enjoy this genre. This game gave me more enjoyment that any other game I played this year (well, technically last year now, I mean in 2014) and in my opinion is a better game than Diablo 3. This game was so good I actually felt bad about not paying the developers so I spent real world money just to show them how much I loved the game. Just make sure you do your research before picking your starting hero since you will be with them for quite a while unless you are planning on spending money. Definitely deserves your attention and time.

reviewText: I have been playing this game since Beta and I honestly regret not dropping $200.00 on this bad boy for the founder's pack.  This has been the greatest Free to Play experience I have ever happened upon.  Gazillion has consistently made this game better with each and every patch.  The business model is brilliant.  I have spent more on costumes than I would have spent buying this game at a $69.99 price tag, and every time I make a frivilous purchase to make a character I love look cooler I feel good about it.  I want this development team to have more money and continue making a fantastic marvel experience.  Every character feels like it came straight out of a comic or movie and if for some reason it doesn't, just post in their forums about it.  The dev team has this revolutionary new working concept where they listen to what the community wants, and then...they give it to them!  Crazy right?  So if you haven't tried Marvel Heroes recently, you have nothing to lose, you can be a total cheapskate and you still have access to the full game and every character just by playing it, so get in here and get raid ready already.

reviewText:
Marvel Heroes is not a great game, it's mediocre at best, BUT it has the bonus that you can play as your favourite hero and it is not a bad game, it is average.

If you are a fan of Marvel comics (or Ultimate Alliance 1&2/X-Men Legends 1&2) you should definitely check it out, for everyone else probably not a good choice, well you can test it for free, that's a bonus.

Important tip for starters:
You don't have to unlock the hero the game gives you, you can unlock any hero as the first hero at the start of the game.
Also you can get the Deadpool Team-Up for free (just search for it online), no need to invest eternity shards or money.

reviewText:
It's fun but once you reach end-game you're stuck on Cosmic Terminal/raid reruns with a huge lack of diversity. I have no complaints about item drops considering the 3-4 artifact drops in one run; it simply gets incredibly boring.

I expected pay to play heroes but not pay to get inventory space... it's a disgustingly awful approach to force you into buying/grinding out (100s of hours - at which you ponder whether dishing out $ will be worth it) for more space. Mind you - I spent $0 on this game.

If you're considering spending money on this game - PLEASE RECONSIDER. I urge you to find a $40-60 game in which you'll find high pleasure from. Especially if you're looking for more team based games because the likelihood of finding online friends is low. I've played World of Warcraft (for about 2 years on and off) and I've made 2 great friends to this date.

10/10 as a new player
0/10 once you reach the level cap and start over... only to realize how much of a waste of time it is.

Long story short:
Play and enjoy the game if you're a new comer, save your money, beat the game, then move onto something else.

reviewText: I plowed a lot of time into this game in beta and i have to say it is a fantastic ARPG that fully embraces the subject matter of the world around it. I will be releveling hawkeye as much as i can. The game comes with the same amount of flair and high production values you would expect of any recent marvel product. My only gripe is how expensive the microtransactions are. Happily if you don't mind playing with a very small set of characters that won't be a problem. If you are an ARPG fan then get this game , if you are a marvel fan get this game....and if not try it out anyway! 8.5/10

reviewText: I'm one of the many who were highly hyped about Marvel Heroes but once it launched I didn't play nearly as much as I imagined I would have.  It lacked something, and there were so many other games that had my attention at the time that it just never grabbed me.  Fast forward to now, I'm coming from Diablo 3: Reaper of Souls.  It was on the Diablo forums I saw someone recommend to Blizzard 'Please make end game content and community events as often and as creative as Gaz does with Marvel Heroes'.  It was that statement that made me go more events?"
date: it peaked my interest so I figured why not go give it a try again.  Installed it up on Steam
hoursPlayed: hopped on Wolverine and had a field day.  There was so much stuff that was new
voteText: which is the biggest compliment I can give this game
helpfulPercent: since launch.  I was probably gone from the game for a good 9-10 months I would say.  Once I got going I never looked back.  In fact I haven't logged back on Diablo 3 and played in nearly 3 weeks.\n\nThis game is has so much endgame and does a successful job in making the inbetween (leveling) a lot of fun.  The community events are great
votesHelpful: from the addition of a new story chapter

10/10

reviewText:
The good far outweighs the bad.

The good:

- New heroes every month
- Dungeon crawling experience
- Great voice actors
- A true free to play experience that does not require you to pay for any characters
- Always re-balancing heroes with fun in mind
- Great story spanning 9 chapters
- Lots of item combinations

The bad:

- Repetition, by level 25 you've finished all of the story, so you start it over on higher difficulty
- Random number generator loves to mess with you, will keep you doing things over and over just to get what you want

Even though there are bad things to say about the game, I do not see them as reasons not to play it. The fact that I don't always get what I want makes me want to keep trying and get it. Knowing that something is right within reach, makes you want to keep reaching. Whether it's a rune, a specific artifact, or even a Unique for your character ... Marvel Heroes will keep you craving more.

If you are the kind of person that disagrees with all of the above, I have only one thing to say to you. Deadpool.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game has a lot going for it. The smooth overhead combat combat makes encounters seemless and the action very fluid. Most players will find the crafting system simplified, but integral to the progression of your character. One of the best crafting features is the ability to transform an outgrown epic item into an epic item that another of your characters can use. The thought of 'The Thing' handing used pants down to 'Storm' is hillarious, but quite practical. You can easily switch between your characters anywhere in the world... but don't get any power leveling ideas, it seems there is some limitation based on the level range of party members.\n\nThe major down side is the lack of a secure trading system or auction hall and currency is never directly tradable. Just toss that item on the floor and anyone can pick it up without concequence. The pay to use product service is expensive as always on F2P games. And remember, purchased pets are completely useless in combat. I rate this as 7 out of 10

reviewText:
Okay. I should start by saying when this game was first released I thought it was not very good. I played Hawkeye and ran through the game and lost interest very soon after. In all honesty when the game was released they should of said it was in beta, because that's exactly what it felt like.

As a kid of the 90's I grew up on Diablo and Diablo II. This game is in that same vein just spliced with my other love of the 90's Marvel comics.  You can choose one of a couple free to play characters and run through an okay story written by Marvel Comics own Bendis. It's full of heroes and villians. Theres characters you can straight up buy characters from the store or go the cheap route and play the game and get randomly dropped splinters that unlock characters.

There is a PVP mode that is in beta and it's not very good.

There is a grind fest mode called Midtown Madness, which is fun to zone out and just level.

There is a mode which is a horde mode where you and a group take on multiple waves of bad guys.

There is loot and a ever expanding world. (As of writing this we just opened up chapter 9 Asguard)

This game is a lot of fun but I that might just be my inner fanboy talking. I would recommend it to anyone who has a love of super heroes and diablo. If you don't care for either you may want to pass on it.

reviewText: Action oriented MMO in the style of Diablo II. Based on the Marvel universe, this free to play release sports some 30 Heroes. All Heroes have Diablo II styled skill trees allowing a variety of customizable options to give the player tactical options within each hero. This is not a simplified game for children but instead a complex hard hitting and high impact action game that stomps on other game of this genre. The gameplay accomidates all playstyles including casual up to extreme aggression. This game being a work of Diablo II devs including Gazzillion CEO David Brevik can be considered the next logical step for the Diablo series and it won't dissapoint hard core Diablo fans.\nFree to play meens: No buying power. Most things can be achieved ingame without purchase. Heroes can be unlocked with ingame currency or with cash allong with costumes which only provide asthetic changes to each hero. Stash tabs are the only thing I've found that you must buy. Priced from around 3.00 for hero tabs to around 5.00 for generaql tabs you will consider putting 10.00 to 20.00 towards inventory.

reviewText:
Things to like:

1) Fans of Torchlight, Diablo, Path of Exile.. and comics. Fast paced clickfest action, tons of loot, skill point builds, etc.

2) Above average graphics, particle effects, environments for those who have decent rigs.

3) Free to play done well with PVE. Splinters are the currency to unlock ingame heroes without spending anything.

4) Fan service galore. Heroes break the 4th wall with random snarky comments to each other. Quests and tooltips often contain comic lore so if you're not a follower of a certain series, you'll get tidbits here and there.

5) From the official forums, the developers constantly interact with the players with questions and feedback. They seem to be dedicated to improving this game with each patch. Especially key is the reworkings of older heroes so they don't get left back as new heroes are being added (similar to what Riot does with older League of Legends champs).

Things that are rough around the edges:

1) For the people who play for endgame, best in slot type gameplay, there will be tons of grinding and repetition. Inventory management is a nightmare if you have multiple heroes and multiple gear loadouts, and it will cost real money.

2) PVP was recently added in a patch (November 2013) and it's unclear yet whether the devs will be able to handle PVP balance and PVE balance (this troubled WoW for years). Also unclear is whether the importance of PVP will hurt the overall Free to Play model.

3) Needs more work on the social aspect. I've joined a Supergroup (aka guild/clan).. but it's like it doesn't even matter. Instance runs seem to be random if you're grouped with someone (they enter the portal around the same time you do). This might be different for players who signed up with their friends and constantly group up, but for a person who is solo yet craves dynamic group play, you've been warned.

Especially key is the reworkings of older heroes so they don't get left back as new heroes are being added (similar to what Riot does with older League of Legends champs).

Things that are rough around the edges:

1) For the people who play for endgame, best in slot type gameplay, there will be tons of grinding and repetition. Inventory management is a nightmare if you have multiple heroes and multiple gear loadouts, and it will cost real money.

2) PVP was recently added in a patch (November 2013) and it's unclear yet whether the devs will be able to handle PVP balance and PVE balance (this troubled WoW for years). Also unclear is whether the importance of PVP will hurt the overall Free to Play model.

3) Needs more work on the social aspect. I've joined a Supergroup (aka guild/clan).. but it's like it doesn't even matter. Instance runs seem to be random if you're grouped with someone (they enter the portal around the same time you do). This might be different for players who signed up with their friends and constantly group up, but for a person who is solo yet craves dynamic group play, you've been warned.

reviewText:
Hack-n-Slash, Diablo-clone, Action RPG. Whatever you'd like to call them, the genre has seen quite a revival as of late. It has always been there, and always surviving, but in recent years they have certainly gained a bit of popularity with the releases of Torchlight 1 and 2, Diablo 3 and, yes, Path of Exile. Driven by nostalgia of the glory days of Diablo 2, thousands of players flock to these releases, hoping for an addictive and endlessly replayable experience. But most have ignored and dismissed one certain game... and that is, of course, Marvel Heroes.

I will admit that Marvel Heroes is far from perfect, and in many ways can be inferior to some of the other products on the market. However, it can also be said that Marvel Heroes is quite different in many ways as well. Rather than trying to directly compete, Marvel Heroes has carved out its own slice of the hack-n-slash pie.

Why do I like Marvel Heroes? Why do I play it? I'll give you all my reasons in a simple format.

1) Marvel Heroes has the Marvel IP -- No swords and sorcery. No warriors and monks. No traditional mages and archers for the billionth time. Here we get super heroes. And with super heroes, anything goes: Teleport. Invincibility. Laser beams. Explosions. Robots. Flight. Invisibility. Monsters. Aliens. Modern setting. Dinosaurs. Ninjas.
Beyond the sheer variety and breath of fresh air, who can deny the fact that playing as a super hero is awesome?

2) Each character is essentially a class --  In other games you create a character based off a certain type of class. In Marvel Heroes, you simply play a character. I'm not going to pretend that they don't have similarities. But even so, each character is still a class of their own. Tired of one? Switch. It's as simple as that. These type of games do get repetitive, but with over 30 characters to choose from, you can always find a new experience.

3) The game is constantly evolving -- They just added pvp. They're constantly changing, tweaking the powers of heroes. A new hero joins the roster every month. They've been adding new mission types, new game modes, they added new equipment, they added Midtown, they've been giving the crafter new recipes. Some heroes may be OP one moment and terrible the next. Yeah, it's often imbalanced with constant buffing and nerfing, but that's due to the ambitious nature of what they're trying to achieve. To some that may sound terrible. But to me, that's exciting... because that means I can look forward to what's in store for the future.

4) It's more of an MMO than most -- In traditional games of this type, most of the game world is instanced. Marvel Heroes does away with this concept by having public areas in addition to smaller instanced areas. This makes it easy to group up with people of your level and do quests. It also means you can experience huge boss fights with tons of crazy powers flying around. Everyone only can see and grab their own loot, so you don't have to worry about butting heads or being begged for an artifact/cosmic that you found.

5) Free to play -- Yeah, not free to get everything you want. Not free to get costumes you want. Not free to have plenty of inventory space to store things. But it's certainly free to play. There's no gameplay gated by a paywall. Play as much as you want. Pay for what you want. The prices are insane. But if you plan on playing for hundreds of hours, why not buy a few things?

reviewText:
Marvel Heroes - The good, The Bad and the Free to play

As of this Review i have only clocked around 45 hours of play time but i am having a blast with the game. It is your standard ARPG with superheroes and like every ARPG they all have there own twists and takes on the genre, but generally you destroy things, pick up loot and develop your character's gear and skills.

Gameplay is fast and frantic and combat is smooth as butter, abilitys are extremly reactive and combat itself has so much weight behind it its crazy - camera shakes, massive crit bubbles sound effects of explosions with death and pain being rained down on the unlucky souls who turned up for work at hydra that day. This is easily where it stands out from other ARPGS on the market today and you really feel like your character is a superhero. This can lead to one issue though, difficulty.

I have only completed the first 2 difficulty levels and i hear that the later zones on the last difficulty ramp up a lot more, the boss fights became a bit harder on herioc but apart from Dr Doom and Loki the other boss's i found a tad easy, the fights themselves are fun but they need to incorporate better phasing with bosses to promote more movement in gameplay - You can basicly go to town on a boss till you need to heal up, take a med pack and carry on.

The good news is there adding a lot more new content this year which is geared towards the issues i just pointed out with both 10 man raiding and Terminal levels designed for high end well geared players that are looking for a very tough challenge.

Currently the game supports quite a few different gameplay modes all based around collecting things to buy things, you have a animated comic that tells you a story as you play for the content which you recieve character upgrades, respec devices, experience boosts and Eternity splinters. (talk about eternity splinters soon) There are also terminals which give you access to other parts of gameplay. For instance these terminals offer varied boss fights for varied dificultys, you can decide how hard you like to make it.

Then you have Midtown madness and X-defence, Midtown madness is an always open map where you have bosses spawning consistantly with lots and lots to kill and is a great little XP earner. X - defence is a wave based game where you and a party needs to defend the X mansion from large mob and boss packs and with each wave you defeat the difficulty scales up.

They have recently added PVP terminal to the game but it is still in BETA and i have not tried this out yet. But with Cosmic Terminals and Raids being added on top of there current content list there will be a lot of ways to improve and build your character. I also forgot to mention there adding a Diablo 2 style Rune system as well.

The Free to play

The free to play system works well for the games setup, but i would like to warn you to do some research on the character your looking on playing first if you do not want to drop any money down straight away. This is because when you start the game you will have a pre determined list of characters, And you can only choose ONE so make sure that character will suit your playstyle. Remember that ALL other characters in game can be earned in game without any payment.

The current starter line up is: Luke Cage, Punisher, Captain America, Black Panther, Black Widow, Human Torch, Colossus, Storm and Hawkeye.

''Ok there all cool but i want spiderman or iron man how do i earn them in game?'' - Well the game drops Eternity Splinters and these splinters are used to purchase everything (including Hero's) that can be paid for in the store, there is an exception though and that is Stash space (place to store your items). This works well though because anybody looking to spend 100's of hours in the game with multiple Heroes will probably want to drop a few dollar so gazillion can pay the bills. Any part time players will not need that much room.

A tip for any UK players is to buy the in game currency directly from there web site as it sells it in dollar not pounds

So far i have dropped 20 pound (35 dollar?) on the game and have 5 Heros unlocked and im working towards my sixth so value for money is very good, but again you dont have to spend anything.

All in all the game is very solid it has a lot to do and they are reviewing and updating each current hero every month to make them more fun while adding new content and new heroes. They really are pushing the boat out to turn around the terrible initial reviews gathered on metacritic. If you like ARPGS and Marvel or find yourself with no enough time to devote to a full blown MMO seriously play the game its fun, free and you have no obligation if you dont like it!!

reviewText: This game is quite awesome. As a comic book fan, I am a huge fan of the storyline of the game and the allusions to situations that occured in comics books. There is a great manipulation of the stories of the marvel universe here. But that's not where the real meat of the game is. There is a huge amount of challenge and random event content, and the whole game is one big lootsplosion. The microtransactions are... a bit disenheartening. But it is possible to get together enough in-game 'eternity splinters' (random drop) and purchase pretty much everything that costs money in the 'G' (premium in-game currency) store. Characters, partners, pets, quipment, it's all obtainable without using real cash. But not without a time investment. The loot aspect of this game, and the many, many ways to improve your character (and, duh, a name like MARVEL) make this game 100% worthy of playing. A truly awesome and addictive gaming experience.

reviewText:
Great game if you're into action RPG's and Marvel Comics.

Marvel Heroes is updated weekly with multiple events, gameplay improvements and more.

Nearly every month Gazillion will add a new hero to expand the already large roster of characters and that includes Team-up characters that you can summon to fight along side you.

Obtaining heroes and team-ups can be done for free but it takes time due to the drop rate of Eternity Splinters.

Gazillion is also very active with the community in regards to improving game mechanics or doing complete overhalls on character skill trees to make them more fun and exciting.

There are also daily login rewards for playing like items, random hero tokens, pets, and more.

The only downside is you'll have to eventually pay cash if you want to buy new stash tabs or if you're too impatient, multiple heroes, items to increase drop rates, team-ups, etc.

All in all this game is great and I highly recommend it.

Also,  Gazillion has won 2 awards this year for Marvel Heroes: The Ten Ton Hammer Award as the GOTY for 2014, and the Most Improved MMO of 2014 (It beat Elder Scrolls Online for that one).

Tons more improvements and Heroes/Team-Ups are coming this year.

My score 8/10

reviewText:
The game plays like a Diablo clone but has MMO elements, parts where you play with other people and instanced levels where you are solo or with a party. The only problem I have is the constant disconnections. I'm not sure why this keeps happening. I haven't lost any character or item progression but I've had to restart the level I was playing.

Anyway, the implementation of skills is good and it has solid gameplay at the very least. The comicbook style story telling is interesting and keeps things fresh. The best part is, you don't have to pay a dime if you don't want to. There are only cosmetic effects to paying and you might be able to level faster than others if you pay. It's definitely not pay to win, which is my main concern with free to play games these days.

I suggest at least trying it out if you have the connection for it. The download size is around 14gb at the time of writing this review.

reviewText: With the hurricane of hype surrounding Avengers: Age of Ultron still fresh in our minds, it seemed only appropriate to revisit Marvel Heroes. The free-to-play action RPG has been humming along for a couple of years now, building a solid community on top of a fair and rewarding in-game economy. Looting and tuning characters to acquire gear faster and heal their wounds forever is the order of the day. This might put off some looking for a deeper experience in their MMO, but those just looking to throw down in their favorite comic book universe have no excuse not to dive into the dungeon-like city streets and blast the Maggia away.\n\nWant to know more? My full review is now up over at TechRaptor.net! https://techraptor.net/content/marvel-heroes-2015-review-no-prize-winner
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
For new players, you have a choice between 11 starting heroes of which you can level all 11 of them to level 10 to try them out to see which one you wish to play as an 'uncap' their level to 60. additionally, with the re-launch, you get bonuses literally every day you login for 300 days straight. you can either buy characters via real $, or buy them with in game currency which drops from mobs called eternity splinters. each hero costs a different amount, but the general idea of them are set at (eternity splinters) 200, 400, and 650. buying via real money is still fairly cheap, although I don't know off the top of my head houw much.

The gameplay is very interesting and quite entertaining. This game really tailors to any fan of ARPG and MMO's alike. It has everything you'd want an ARPG to have while retaining MMO qualities with some underqualifying regime but still unbelievably enjoyable. While leveling through the story, if at any time you get bored. you can do instances to quench your thirst for mobs with a boss spawn, go to Xaviers school to fend off waves of enemies, do patrol with infinite spawning mobs, bosses, and events, and almost anything else you could think of that an ARPG or MMO has. The idea of wide scale gamer caitoring is strong with this one. I believe it's the best of it's class due to having such a wide array of content to do. Being still somewhat new, the raid content is somewhat limited, it's still worth the effort to put in and try things out. I just can't wait to see how this game pans out in a few years!

The best ideas are yet to come with this game. The CEO of Gaz, and the help of Marvel and Disney, this game will stay close to any current and upcoming storylines as in contract per Marvel and Disney. You can only imagine the possibilities with how this game will work out!

You'd be insane NOT to try this game out. It's free, and you can keep it free. The only thing is that you do have limited space with keeping it free, so don't horde things. I wouldn't bother as most people in game drop gear they don't want or need anyway! The community is very helpful and interested in that too, which is a big help for those that don't like to read the help section on 'what to do'.

reviewText:
At first glance, this game looks like fanservice crap. However, it fills in a nice niche in the diablo-like family. If you're looking to scratch your diablo itch and you're bored with Diablo 3, I'd recommend this game. If you like super heroes, (who doesn't?) then you will enjoy it even more.

It also has an MMO twist. In my opinion, it's everything Diablo 3 should have been in terms of the multiplayer.

If you can get past the rough edges, this game will be the addictive diablo fix you're looking for. It's also free, and anything you can buy with real money is easy to get.

reviewText: With the hurricane of hype surrounding Avengers: Age of Ultron still fresh in our minds, it seemed only appropriate to revisit Marvel Heroes. The free-to-play action RPG has been humming along for a couple of years now, building a solid community on top of a fair and rewarding in-game economy. Looting and tuning characters to acquire gear faster and heal their wounds forever is the order of the day. This might put off some looking for a deeper experience in their MMO, but those just looking to throw down in their favorite comic book universe have no excuse not to dive into the dungeon-like city streets and blast the Maggia away.\n\nWant to know more? My full review is now up over at TechRaptor.net! https://techraptor.net/content/marvel-heroes-2015-review-no-prize-winner

reviewText:
Marvel Heroes 2015 is a third person bird's eye view action game where you control one unit with a variety of moves you can use on a hotbar. Think Diablo 3 mechanics. It does set itself apart in ways other than the properties though. For one, it's technically an MMO. There are various hubs like Avengers Tower or Odin's Palace where you'll find plenty of other players above the 4 or 8 person limits of some games of this type.

For another, loot visuals. These characters that you're playing are well-established Marvel Comics characters like the X-Men or Avengers. They have years of visuals to draw on, but each appearance is its own separate thing. With this in mind, instead of each piece of loot having its own appearance on your character, there's only one slot that affects the visual makeup of your character - the costume slot. You start with the default, but can buy different costumes. So while you might start as standard Mark IV Iron Man, you can buy his Hulkbuster Armor, or Starburst, or Heartbreaker, or any of the movie costumes for a few bucks, and they alter what your character looks like in game. It's really a good move because instead of clownsuited dudes running around, you get set outfits that pay homage to plenty of well and lesser known versions of the character that have shown up in the comics and movies over the years. Did you know Colossus once gained the powers of Juggernaut, and wore the iconic helmet? How about Captain America's stint as Director of SHIELD, complete with a shield made of hard energy instead of metal? There's lots of options for appearance.

The game is a love letter to each character's past, with every piece of loot from common to unique having a quote on it tailored for the character or item. Comic references abound in this game, they're everywhere - the loot, the voice acting, the enemies, the story. It's all good stuff.

Most importantly though, it plays well. Much better than it did when it originally released. If you're a fan of the comics, give it a try. If you like Diablo-style games give it a try. This one is much faster paced than what you're probably used to. Every single character has at least one decent travel power with no cooldown that can be spammed to traverse the map. Some are faster than others (Nightcrawler can teleport across the entirety of Midtown in a few seconds whereas Wolverine riding a motorcycle might take more like 30 seconds), but they're ALL at least as mobile as the Monk from D3 with Dashing Strike (any of the runes). If you gotta go fast, this game does it. There's a common artifact that gives you teleport, as well.

There's plenty of interesting content, and there's a lot of challenging content as well. Cosmic difficulty terminals are fun to farm and have some tough enemies to fight. This game even has raiding, which is unique for this genre. Two levels of difficulty, in ten player groups. In addition to a story mode, raids, and cosmic terminals (akin to bounties from D3), there are also two endless wave modes (X-Defense and SHIELD Holo-Sim) and three one-shot stories (think a few dungeons worth of enemies to clear followed by one or two difficult bosses that drop really nice loot). All can be done either solo or with groups, and you can choose to be auto-paired or to go by yourself.

By this point, there are more than enough characters that everyone who is a fan of the Marvel universe will have one of their favorites available to play. The developer is constantly updating and presenting new content (a new character every month or two is standard), and it's very easy to farm up the in-game currency to buy new heroes with, instead of paying money. A week or two of regular play will probably yield enough currency to buy any but the most expensive tier of heroes. Definitely a great approach to the F2P model, which seems to have been contaminated with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t lately.

TLDR: Like Marvel comics/movies? Like Diablo? You'll like it. Try it. Just logging in on the second day gives you enough currency to buy almost any hero for free right off the bat.

reviewText:
I use to have zero interest in the whole superhero genre. Comics? Meh. Movies? Cheesy. But on a whim, probably because I had seen many people I know giving it a shot, decided to give Marvel Heroes a shot myself. The game is a Diablo-clone that feels like it does Diablo better than Diablo.

Marvel Heroes is instantly fun from the very beginning, where you choose between an array of iconic characters and start beating on the bad guys. Since the game is free-to-play, there is a reliance on the cash shop, but the meat of the game, the heroes, are very easily obtained just through gameplay and logging in. The only items that I have really felt compelled to purchase through the shop is just more inventory space, and I only needed more inventory space as I'm finding it more and more fun to level up a bunch of different characters. All other items in the game are easily attainable through play or through one of the never-ending series of events.

And now? I'm almost caught up on watching all the superhero movies that Marvel has come out with, can't wait to watch the next episode of Daredevil in my Netflix queue, and I can't wait to see more of the movies as they come out. I still don't know about the comics yet, but I'm definitely much more of a superhero fan than I was, and I have to thank Marvel Heroes for that.

reviewText: This game has come a long way in it's time. I love the continuing addition of characters to the already impressive roster, as well as the ongoing development to the gameplay itself, both which break the tedium of post regulation gaming. A casual gamer wont get the full experience as creating a powerful roster takes a lot of play time, but it's also a game that's easy to pick back up after a few months away. It's a free game, so you might as well try it.

reviewText: Very enjoyable, completely playable for free, the only thing you I have really felt a need to spend money on is storage space which is intentionally limited and you have to deal with a large number of items that you will want to retain for crafting or upgrading.  Still haven't felt much need to spend more than $5-10 so very reasonable design.  Plays like Diablo 2, which is a good thing and definitely feels like you are playing a hero in a comic...very happy with the game so far.  Also multiple mechanisms for obtaining most of the purchaseables, costumes, hero's etc. with in game currency.  Wish there was a mail system or some sort of AH for some of the items.
